questions.prompt: Do other things besides food DECAY?
Do most people like to be MISERABLE?
Do the leaves of trees TREMBLE when the wind blows through them?
Is an Olympic gold medal a TROPHY?
Are some people TERRIFIED of the dark?
Are all TERRITORIES the same size?
If you take frozen food out of the freezer, will it THAW?
Do people usually say "Hello" when they DEPART?
Do people usually HOLLER in the library?
Are people who are watching a baseball game PARTICIPATING in it?
Is someone who learns a language in a few months a RAPID learner?
Would a store usually REFUND your money if you returned an item that you had broken?
Can a wink be a RESPONSE?
Can a piece of paper be SCORCHED?
She DECAYED it until it was all used up.
I'm sorry I hurt you; I didn't mean to make you MISERABLE.
She TREMBLED the cup of coffee onto the floor.
Each year the winning team receives a large TROPHY.
They gave us a choice, so we ELECTED to stay here.
The news that there was no school today filled us all with TERROR.
The explorers came upon a TERRITORY they had never heard of before.
When the temperature dropped below zero, everything began to THAW.
Their DEPARTURE was a sad event for those of us who stayed behind.
She HOLLERED for help when she saw the monster.
They wanted the whole school to PARTICIPATE in selecting a nickname for the team.
He became very RAPID whenever anyone disagreed with him.
If you mail in this coupon, we will send you a fifty-cent REFUND.
We had to wait three weeks for a RESPONSE to our request for a new telephone.
They SCORCHED the sink so that it would be completely clean.

DECAY.deftext:
to rot, spoil, go bad 
DECAY means to _rot_ or _go bad_, to _spoil_. The word usually suggests a slow natural change from a good condition to a worse one. The word can be used about physical changes or about the breakdown of the mind, morals, or the like. 
"The apples ripened, fell off the tree, and then DECAYED." 
"The stink of the DECAYING garbage was overpowering." 
"His athletic skills had DECAYED from lack of practice." 
DECAY is also a noun which means _rot_ or _ruin_. 
"In that section of town many old houses were abandoned and had fallen into a state of DECAY." 
"He brushed his teeth every day to prevent tooth DECAY."

MISERABLE.deftext:
unhappy, wretched, worthless, very uncomfortable 
MISERY is a state of suffering and great unhappiness. 
"They tried to make her feel better, but no one could relieve her MISERY." 
MISERABLE means "full of MISERY," _unhappy_. See _-able_ under Suffixes. 
"Her cold made her feel MISERABLE." 
"The dog was MISERABLE when its master went away." 
MISERABLE can also mean "causing MISERY," _wretched_. 
"This MISERABLE rainy weather has got to end." 
"They lived in MISERABLE conditions in the slum." 
Other forms of the word: MISERY, n.

TREMBLE.deftext:
to shake, shiver, shudder 
TREMBLE means to _shake_ or _shiver_, because of fear, cold, anger, or even sickness. 
"He was so angry that his voice TREMBLED when he tried to speak." 
"When he came out of the water, his lips were blue with cold and he TREMBLED all over." 
"The needle TREMBLED slightly and then stopped on zero."

TROPHY.deftext:
a prize, award 
A TROPHY is something that is given to a person in memory of a victory or a success. It could be a statue, a medal, a cup, or something similar. 
"He keeps his bowling TROPHIES in a special cabinet." 
"The TROPHY for the top student is a plaque with his or her name on it."

ELECT.deftext:
to choose, select by vote, decide upon, pick out 
To ELECT basically means to choose, and is sometimes used in this way: 
"We ELECTED to go home first." 
Usually, though, ELECT means "to choose among candidates for a political office." 
"When someone is ELECTED president, he is chosen by the voters to be president." 
"Alice was ELECTED class treasurer by fifty-seven votes." 
An ELECTION is an act of choosing. In an ELECTION, voters choose whom they want to be in office. An ELECTIVE course is one which the student may choose to take, as opposed to a course which he is required to take. 
Other forms of the word: ELECTION, n. ELECTIVE, adj.

TERRIFY.deftext:
to scare, frighten, fill with fear 
To TERRIFY someone is to make him extremely scared or frightened, to the point where he almost loses his senses. "He is TERRIFIED of fire." 
"Don't TERRIFY the child with those foolish ghost stories." 
The noun from TERRIFY is TERROR. TERROR is great fear or horror. 
"The sound of the bombs falling filled them with TERROR." 
"The king ruled not by kindness, but by TERROR." 
Other forms of the word: TERROR, n.

TERRITORY.deftext:
an area, district, region, land 
A TERRITORY is an area of land belonging to a person or government. Animals also have TERRITORIES, which are the areas they consider theirs, and which they will defend against other animals. 
"The backyard fence marks the boundary of my cat's TERRITORY." 
"Several tribes held the large TERRITORY in common." 
Districts assigned to traveling salespeople are called TERRITORIES also. "Mr. Smith's TERRITORY covers all of New York state outside of New York City." 
Other forms of the word: TERRITORIAL, adj.

THAW.deftext:
to melt, become liquid, become unfrozen. 
THAW means to _melt_, to _become unfrozen_. 
"It was several weeks before the last of the ice THAWED." 
"I forgot to THAW the meat for supper." THAW is often used in a broader sense about feelings that become warmer. 
"They had been enemies for years, but finally relations between them THAWED." 
THAW is also a noun. "After the spring THAW the streets were inches deep in water."

DEPART.deftext:
to go away, leave 
To DEPART is to go away. 
"They stayed here for three days and then DEPARTED." 
"Our ship DEPARTS next week." 
"We were having such an enjoyable time at the show that we didn't want to DEPART." 
"We DEPARTED from our usual habit of going to bed early." 
The noun from DEPART is DEPARTURE. 
"The bad weather delayed the plane's DEPARTURE." 
Other forms of the word: DEPARTURE, n.

HOLLER.deftext:
to yell, shout, cry out 
To HOLLER is to _shout_, to _make a loud noise_, usually because you are excited, unhappy, or want to get someone's attention. 
"Sally HOLLERED to her friends across the lake." 
"He HOLLERED for help, but no one came." "He was so afraid that he started to HOLLER when anyone came near him." 
"Don't HOLLER; I can hear you perfectly well."

PARTICIPATE.deftext:
to take part in, share in 
To PARTICIPATE in something is to _take part_ in it. You can see the word _part_ in PARTICIPATE. 
"Everyone must PARTICIPATE in the singing." 
"It's hard to play a football game if no one else wants to PARTICIPATE." 
"The teacher asked us to PARTICIPATE in the discussion." 
A PARTICIPANT is someone who PARTICIPATES. 
"All the PARTICIPANTS in the show should be congratulated." 
Other forms of the word: PARTICIPANT, n. PARTICIPATION, n. Usage: PARTICIPATE is usually followed by in.

RAPID.deftext:
quick, fast, speedy, swift 
RAPID is another word for _fast_. 
"We are making RAPID progress toward solving the problem." 
"The student gave RAPID answers to all of the teacher's questions." 
"We walked RAPIDLY along the dark street." 
The noun from RAPID is RAPIDITY. 
"Their RAPIDITY makes it hard for us to keep up with them." 
"We were amazed at the RAPIDITY with which she solved the problem." 
Other forms of the word: RAPIDITY, n.

REFUND.deftext:
to pay back, repay, give back 
REFUND means to _pay back_. See _re-_ under Prefixes. It is usually used when speaking of money. 
"If you are not fully satisfied with our product, we will cheerfully REFUND your money." 
"He paid them too much, so they REFUNDED the extra amount to him." 
REFUND is also a noun, meaning a repayment. 
"She paid too much in taxes to the government, so they sent her a REFUND." 
When used as a noun, the word is pronounced rE'-fuhnd.

RESPONSE.deftext:
an answer, reply 
To RESPOND to something is to say something in return, to _answer_. 
"When asked about her health, she RESPONDED that she had never felt better." 
RESPONSE is the noun from RESPOND. A RESPONSE is an _answer_, a _reply_. 
"When the teacher asked who had thrown the pencil, there was no RESPONSE." 
"I asked him if he would go, and his RESPONSE was that it would depend on the weather." 
A RESPONSE doesn't have to be spoken. 
"When they asked him a rude question, his RESPONSE was to slam the door in their faces." 
Other forms of the word: RESPOND, v.

SCORCH.deftext:
to burn slightly To SCORCH something is to burn it slightly, usually just on the surface. Often something that has been SCORCHED turns brown or dries up. 
"The leaves were SCORCHED by the hot sun." 
"He SCORCHED his shirt when he tried to iron it." 
"The meat was SCORCHED when she left it in the oven for too long." 
Other forms of the word: SCORCHING, adj.

questions.prompt: Does pain usually ACCOMPANY an injury?
Do banks give people PERMISSION to rob them?
Do you GREET people when they leave?
Would most people like COUNTERFEIT money for their pay?
Do people DISCUSS things they keep secret?
Do people like to DISCARD money?
Is it fun to have an ACHE?
Is it hard to OVERCOME a powerful enemy?
Would a person who tries to save people trapped in a burning building be called COURAGEOUS?
Is Washington's Birthday an ANNUAL holiday?
Do people often live in LOBBIES?
He hated people, so he always found someone to ACCOMPANY him.
David wasn't PERMITTED to leave his room until he said he was sorry.
Susan GREETED us with a warm smile.
I could see at a glance that the stamp was a COUNTERFEIT.
No one listened to our DISCUSSION of Egyptian mummies.
Instead of DISCARDING the old furniture he fixed it up and sold it.
The flu made Jane ACHE all over.
We OVERCAME and stayed a few nights at our friend's house.
The force of the car crash made the telephone pole QUIVER.
He ran away after he broke the window because he was afraid to be NOURISHED.
It was COURAGEOUS of him to run away when the other children were in trouble.
She takes her ANNUAL vacation the first two weeks in August.
He stood in the LOBBY trying to decide which elevator to take.
Bill CONTRIBUTED his lack of success to bad luck.
By the time she finished eating, her lipstick was all SMUDGED.

ACCOMPANY.deftext:
to go with, be with 
You can see the word _company_ in ACCOMPANY. To ACCOMPANY someone is to be _in company_ with him, to go along with him. 
"We will ACCOMPANY him as far as the bus stop." 
"The president arrived, ACCOMPANIED by several Secret Service men." 
"High winds ACCOMPANIED the snowstorm." 
ACCOMPANY is often used in the field of music. 
"The singer will be ACCOMPANIED by a pianist."

PERMIT.deftext:
to allow, authorize, make possible 
To PERMIT something is to allow it, to give your consent to it. 
"Her father PERMITTED her to go to the dance." 
"Smoking is not PERMITTED inside the building." The noun from PERMIT is PERMISSION, which is the act of allowing. 
"She was given PERMISSION to speak to the class." 
"The airport denied the plane PERMISSION to land." 
PERMIT (pronounced PER-mit) is also a noun, meaning PERMISSION, especially PERMISSION in written form such as a certificate or license, which allows someone to do something. 
"The school parking PERMIT was pasted on his car's windshield." 
Other forms of the word: PERMISSION, n. 
PERMISSIVE, adj. 
PERMISSIBLE, adj.

GREET.deftext:
to welcome, meet 
To GREET someone is to welcome him, to say hello to him in a friendly way. 
"We all went over to GREET the new neighbors." 
"Is that any way to GREET an old friend?" 
GREET can also mean to _meet_ or _receive_. 
"The play was GREETED with polite applause." 
"They GREETED his speech with boos and hisses." 
A GREETING is the act or words that you use to GREET someone. 
"He received a warm GREETING when he arrived home." 
Other forms of the word: GREETING, n.

COUNTERFEIT.deftext:
fake, phony, not genuine 
COUNTERFEIT can be an adjective, a noun, or a verb. As an adjective, COUNTERFEIT means _fake_ or _phony_. 
"They tried to spend the COUNTERFEIT money as if it were real." 
"She was caught with the COUNTERFEIT dollar bills in her possession." 
A COUNTERFEIT (noun) is a copy or imitation which someone pretends is the real thing, usually in order to cheat a person. 
"The expert said the supposedly priceless painting was a COUNTERFEIT and actually wasn't worth anything." 
Finally, COUNTERFEIT is a verb meaning to fake or pretend. 
"Jane COUNTERFEITED great joy at the gift of the pocketbook. She really thought it was ugly." 
Many people choose _useless_ as the meaning of COUNTERFEIT. COUNTERFEIT money may be useless, but the basic meaning is _fake_, _not genuine_.

DISCUSS.deftext:
to talk about, talk over 
To DISCUSS something is to talk about it, to exchange opinions about it. 
"We DISCUSSED where the picture should be hung." 
"The teacher DISCUSSED the meanings of various words." 
"I want to DISCUSS your behavior with you." 
"It's hard to DISCUSS anything with Tim. He just gets excited and starts yelling." 
The noun from DISCUSS is DISCUSSION. 
"We had a long DISCUSSION about how to do the job." 
Other forms of the word: DISCUSSION, n.

DISCARD.deftext:
to throw away, get rid of 
See _dis-_ under Prefixes. DISCARD means to _throw away_. The word was first used only about throwing away cards that weren't useful in games like poker or gin rummy. 
"He picked up the queen of spades and DISCARDED the two of clubs." 
Now DISCARD is used to indicate throwing away anything that isn't useful. 
"Sheila DISCARDED some old, broken toys." 
"I wanted to DISCARD the book, but since he said it might be valuable, I kept it."

ACHE.deftext:
a dull pain 
An ACHE is a dull, steady pain. 
"Jane felt an ACHE in her legs after she had been running for an hour." 
"Cold, wet weather always caused an ACHE in his injured knee." 
ACHE is also a verb, meaning "to feel a dull steady pain." 
"His head ACHED from all the noise in the room." 
ACHE is often used in the sense "to long for something so much that it is almost painful." 
"She ACHED to see him one last time before she left."

OVERCOME.deftext:
to defeat, surmount, conquer 
To OVERCOME something is to get the better of it. You can OVERCOME a person, a feeling, or a thing. 
"It may take years, but we will OVERCOME the enemy." "He OVERCAME the urge to smoke a cigarette." 
To be OVERCOME _by_ or _with_ something is to be weakened or overpowered by it. 
"She was OVERCOME with sadness when she remembered what he had said." 
"They were OVERCOME by the gas fumes escaping from the car."

QUIVER.deftext:
to shake, tremble 
To QUIVER is to shake or tremble slightly. It is more often used about things than about people. 
"The needle QUIVERED for a while, then stopped on zero." 
"The arrow QUIVERED in the target." 
"The animal QUIVERED with fear as the men approached." 
In the Pretest, many people choose _freeze_ as the meaning of QUIVER, probably because QUIVER looks like _shiver_, and you shiver when its very cold.

NOURISHMENT.deftext:
food, sustenance 
To NOURISH something is to keep it alive and strong by feeding. 
"They needed to NOURISH their plants, so they bought some special plant food." 
NOURISHMENT is that which supports life and growth; it is food or anything else that NOURISHES. 
"Even when you are sick and don't feel like eating, you must still take some NOURISHMENT." 
"Just as your body needs food, your mind needs NOURISHMENT too." 
Other forms of the word: NOURISH, v.

COURAGEOUS.deftext:
having COURAGE, brave, fearless COURAGEOUS comes from the word COURAGE, which means _bravery_. See _-ous_ under Suffixes. COURAGEOUS means _brave_, _fearless_, _having courage_. 
"It was very COURAGEOUS of him to stand up for what he felt was right in the face of the others' disapproval." 
"Her COURAGEOUS attempt to swim the English Channel was unsuccessful." 
"COURAGEOUS people do not run and hide when things become dangerous." 
Other forms of the word: COURAGE, n.

ANNUAL.deftext:
yearly ANNUAL means "coming or happening every year." 
"We will put on our seventh ANNUAL flower show this spring." 
"The party was so successful we decided to make it an ANNUAL event." 
"His ANNUAL income went up ten percent last year."

LOBBY.deftext:
an entrance hall, waiting room 
A LOBBY is a hall, room, or corridor that is used as an entrance or waiting area. 
"He sat and waited in the LOBBY of the hotel until his friends came downstairs." 
The LOBBIES of places like the Senate or the House of Representatives were where members of Congress would meet with the public. A LOBBY has therefore also come to mean a group of people who attempt to influence lawmakers to vote in a certain way. 
"The shipping industry LOBBY spent a great deal of money trying to get this bill passed." 
A LOBBYIST is someone who attempts to influence lawmakers in this way. Other forms of the word: LOBBYIST, n.

CONTRIBUTE.deftext:
to give, donate CONTRIBUTE has two related meanings. First, CONTRIBUTE means "to give along with others." The word is usually used about giving money to a charity, but it can be used about giving other things as well. 
"She CONTRIBUTED several good ideas to the project." 
"If everyone CONTRIBUTES a few hours of his time the house will be painted very quickly." 
CONTRIBUTE can also mean "to help bring about." 
"Extreme tiredness CONTRIBUTED to his coming down with a very bad cold." 
"A good education CONTRIBUTED to his success in politics." 
A CONTRIBUTION, the noun from CONTRIBUTE, is a gift. 
"She has made many CONTRIBUTIONS to charity in the past year." 
Other forms of the word: CONTRIBUTION, n.

SMUDGE.deftext:
a dirty mark, smear, dirt 
A SMUDGE is a blurred, streaky mark, the kind that is made when a bit of dirt is rubbed, or when something is incompletely erased. 
"There were SMUDGES on the window where the child had put his greasy fingers." 
"The paper was covered with SMUDGES after she had finished erasing all her mistakes." 
SMUDGE is also a verb. 
"He SMUDGED the paper even more when he tried to clean it up." 
"She SMUDGED her cheek when she rubbed it with her dirty hand."

questions.prompt: Can a parrot IMITATE the sound of human speech?

Do most students ACHIEVE perfect grades on all their exams?

The tree didn't give us enough SHELTER from the rain, so we ran into the house.

When they saw the big dog APPROACH them, they ran away as fast as they could.
They were not allowed to keep the treasure they RECOVERED from the sunken ship.
Paul ABBREVIATED the rope in half with a knife.

IMITATE.deftext:
to copy, follow the example of, try to be like 
To IMITATE something is to try to be like it, to copy it. You can IMITATE a person or a thing. 
"He tried to IMITATE the sound of a duck." 
"She wants to IMITATE the figure skaters she sees on television." 
An IMITATION is something that is a copy of something else. 
"The building is an IMITATION of an ancient Greek temple." 
"He did a funny IMITATION of a man slipping on a banana peel." 
Other forms of the word: IMITATION, n.

SQUIRM.deftext:
to twist about, wiggle, wriggle 
To SQUIRM means "to twist the body about," to _wiggle_ or _wriggle_. 
"The baby SQUIRMED so much I almost dropped him." 
"He's trying to SQUIRM through the cellar window." 
People often twist about when they feel uncomfortable or embarrassed, and SQUIRM is also used to express this sense. 
"Try not to SQUIRM in your chair while I introduce you to my uncle."

SOCIABLE.deftext:
friendly, liking company, companionable 
SOCIABLE means "liking the company of other people," _friendly_. A SOCIABLE person just naturally likes to be with other people, even if they are strangers. 
"They are a SOCIABLE couple, always inviting friends over." 
"We played a SOCIABLE game of poker." 
"We always enjoy the company of SOCIABLE people." 
SOCIABLE is the opposite of hostile or unfriendly. You cannot, for example, have a SOCIABLE fight.

ACHIEVE.deftext:
to gain, accomplish, get 
ACHIEVE means to gain or to get, often with some degree of difficulty. 
"He ACHIEVED his goal of learning to walk again after he had been crippled." 
"She realized that it was necessary to study to ACHIEVE an A in math." 
"Most of us have to work hard to ACHIEVE any success." 
The noun from ACHIEVE is ACHIEVEMENT, which means an accomplishment. 
"His greatest ACHIEVEMENT was to score the winning touchdown." 
"She is not content to get by on her previous ACHIEVEMENTS, but is always looking for new fields to conquer." 
Other forms of the word: ACHIEVEMENT, n.

RESEMBLE.deftext:
to be like, look like, act like 
RESEMBLE means "to be like or look like" somebody or something. 
"She RESEMBLES her mother, particularly around the eyes." 
"The twins don't RESEMBLE each other at all." 
"The son RESEMBLES his father in his patience and good humor." 
The noun from RESEMBLE is RESEMBLANCE. 
"The RESEMBLANCE between distant relatives is often remarkable." 
Other forms of the word: RESEMBLANCE, n.

SHELTER.deftext:
protection, safety 
SHELTER is used in two senses. First, it is a building or place that gives protection. 
"After half an hour they reached the ski SHELTER." 
"We stood in the bus SHELTER to keep out of the strong wind." 
Second, SHELTER means protection itself. 
"We tried to find SHELTER from the heavy rain." 
"The family sought SHELTER in their basement from the bombs." 
SHELTER is also used as a verb and means to protect. 
"The doorway of the building SHELTERED us from the storm." 
"The beach umbrella SHELTERS us from the burning sun."

GRASP.deftext:
to take, take hold of, seize, clutch; to understand, comprehend To GRASP something is to take hold of it. 
"He GRASPED the handlebars of his bicycle." 
"She GRASPED the cup firmly with both hands so that it wouldn't fall." GRASP is also used to mean "to take hold of mentally," to _understand_. 
"I fail to GRASP how your plan will help us." 
"It took a lot of explaining, but finally Jim seemed to GRASP the idea."

STUMBLE.deftext:
to trip, walk unsteadily, make a mistake 
To STUMBLE is to trip and almost fall, often as the result of hitting something that is in your way. 
"The hidden wire caused him to STUMBLE, but he managed to stay on his feet." 
To STUMBLE is also to walk along unsteadily, to stagger, as if you were about to fall at any second. 
"The drunk STUMBLED along, barely able to stand up." 
In general use the word can also mean "to speak or act clumsily," to blunder or founder. 
"Johnny STUMBLED over every word as he tried to read the sentence." 
"We didn't know anything about it, so we just STUMBLED along, doing the best we could."

SHATTER.deftext:
to break SHATTER means "to break into small pieces." 
SHATTER is used in connection with glass or anything like glass that breaks easily. 
"The bottle rolled off the table and SHATTERED on the floor." 
"The windshield SHATTERED when the car hit the tree." 
SHATTER can be used in a broader sense about health, hopes, dreams, nerves, and the like. 
"His nerves were SHATTERED by the terrible battle."

STOOP.deftext:
to bend down, bow down, lower oneself 
To STOOP is to bend down from the waist. 
"Jim STOOPED over to pick up a dime on the floor." 
"He STOOPED so that he wouldn't hit his head on the pipe." 
From this physical sense STOOP has come to mean "to do something that is beneath you" in terms of either rank or morals. 
"How could you STOOP to telling such an awful lie?" 
"Why did the famous actor STOOP to doing television commercials?"

DOWNCAST.deftext:
depressed, sad, discouraged 
The word cast in DOWNCAST means _throw_, and DOWNCAST was originally a verb which meant to _throw down_ or _overthrow_. Now DOWNCAST is only used as an adjective to describe spirits or looks that are "thrown down" because something sad has happened. 
"We tried to cheer him up because he seemed DOWNCAST." 
"You look so DOWNCAST. What's wrong?" 
"Bobby has a right to be DOWNCAST. His fumble cost us the game." 
"Almost everyone feels DOWNCAST on a gray, gloomy day."

SPROUT.deftext:
to spring up, begin to grow, send out leaves or buds 
To SPROUT means to _spring up_, to _begin to grow_. SPROUT is most often used about plants or other growing things, but it has also come to be used about anything that grows suddenly or quickly. 
"Because of the sudden increase in population, new towns SPROUTED up almost overnight." 
"When he was fourteen his beard began to SPROUT." 
SPROUT can also mean "to cause to grow, to send out new leaves." 
"The tree SPROUTED new buds in the spring." 
Usage: SPROUT is often followed by _up_.

APPROACH.deftext:
to near, come near 
APPROACH means to _come near_ or _get near_. 
"We all felt relieved as we watched him APPROACH us without tripping." 
"What is the right way to APPROACH the king's throne?" 
"She was APPROACHING the age to leave home." 
APPROACH is also a noun that means a _road_ or _way_ to something. When APPROACH is used to mean _way_, it can be used in either the sense of a _path_ or a _method_. 
"We'll have to use another APPROACH (method) to get him to agree." 
"The APPROACH (path) to the highway was blocked by snow."

RECOVER.deftext:
to get back; to become well 
To RECOVER something is to get or win it back. See _re-_ under Prefixes. 
"She RECOVERED the ring she had lost." 
"They RECOVERED his shoe from the bottom of the pond." 
"You'll never RECOVER all the money you have wasted." 
When a person RECOVERS _from_ something, he gets better, becomes well. 
"He RECOVERED from the sickness." 
"She is fully RECOVERED from her accident." 
RECOVERY (the noun) is the act of getting back or getting better. 
"He was pleased by the quick RECOVERY of his lost wallet." 
"Her RECOVERY from the illness will take many months." 
Other forms of the word: RECOVERY, n.

ABBREVIATE.deftext:
to shorten 
To ABBREVIATE something is to make it shorter by leaving out parts. The word is used particularly when talking about the shortening of words and phrases. 
"The words 'United States of America' are ABBREVIATED to "USA". 
"His name was Albert, but he ABBREVIATED it to Al in order to save space." 
ABBREVIATE can be used about other things as well. 
"The mayor's speech had to be ABBREVIATED because we ran out of time." 
The noun from ABBREVIATE is ABBREVIATION. 
"Mr. is the ABBREVIATION for Mister." 
Other forms of the word: ABBREVIATION, n.

questions.prompt: Does a penny REPRESENT a lot of money?
Does a horse usually run faster when the rider LASHES it?
Can you RELY on a liar to tell the truth?
Can you SOB while holding your breath?
Do nervous people sometimes PACE back and forth?
Is there more than one METHOD for learning how to swim?
Is it possible to REGAIN something you never had?
Do most people have an OPPORTUNITY to go to the moon?
Can a fly buzzing around a person's head be IRRITATING?
Is it more polite to REQUEST something than to demand it?
The angry man LASHED out at everyone who criticized him.
Blanche said that she had always RELIED on the kindness of strangers.
She SOBBED with laughter at the funny jokes.
He was going at such a fast PACE that no one could keep up with him.
It seems that every week someone comes up with a new METHOD for teaching arithmetic.
The soldiers RETREATED to attack the enemy.
He is very RECKLESS about his health; he eats too much, smokes too much, and drinks too much.
Bob SWIFTLY recovered the fumble and raced for a touchdown.
It took several weeks for him to REGAIN confidence in his driving ability after the terrible accident.
He just never had the OPPORTUNITIES to succeed that we have had.
The rash on her arm was further IRRITATED by her constant scratching.
He REQUESTED that we stop talking.
She wore beautiful POSES around her neck.
He INVESTIGATED the possibility of buying a new car.

REPRESENT.deftext:
to stand for, act for, portray 
To REPRESENT something is to stand for it, to be a picture or sign of it. 
"The flag is a symbol that REPRESENTS our country." 
"These written notes REPRESENT musical sounds." 
"The scenery in the play is supposed to REPRESENT an African jungle." 
To REPRESENT also means to _speak_ or _act for_ someone or something. 
"Bill will REPRESENT our school at the track meet." 
"Senator Jones REPRESENTS our state in Congress." 
Other forms of the word: REPRESENTATION, n. REPRESENTATIVE, adj.

LASH.deftext:
to strike, whip, beat 
To LASH someone is to hit him with a whip, or as if with a whip. 
"He LASHED the thief twenty times for punishment." 
"He LASHED the horse with his whip." 
"The rain LASHED against the windows." 
To give someone a "tongue-LASHING" is to speak to him very angrily, to make him feel as if you were LASHING him with a whip. To LASH _out_ at someone is to attack him violently, with words or blows. 
"In his talk the coach LASHED out at the players who didn't try."

RELY.deftext:
to depend, trust, have faith 
To RELY _on_ or _upon_ someone is to depend on them, to put your trust in them. 
"I RELIED on him to help me out." 
"We're RELYING on you to keep our secret." 
"He can be RELIED on to get us to the airport on time." 
The noun form of RELY is RELIANCE, which means trust, confidence. 
"We place our RELIANCE on you to get us out of trouble." 
The adjective is RELIABLE. Someone who is RELIABLE can be RELIED upon. 
"He is a RELIABLE worker. You can count on him to do the job right." 
Other forms of the word: RELIABLE, adj. RELIANCE, n. Usage: RELY is usually followed by on or upon.

SOB.deftext:
to cry, weep 
To SOB is to cry in gasping bursts, while taking sharp breaths. 
"She SOBBED in relief that the child was not injured." 
"We heard him SOBBING quietly in his room." 
SOB is also a noun. 
"We couldn't understand what the unhappy child was saying as she tried to talk between SOBS." 
"The first angry crying gave way to long SOBS." 
"His chest heaved with SOBS."

PACE.deftext:
a step; rate of moving 
A PACE is a step in walking or running. 
"He took a PACE or two and then stopped." It is also the distance of a step. 
"She measured off six PACES from the tree." 
The word is also used to indicate the rate of walking or moving. 
"He worked at a steady PACE all day long." 
"He changed his PACE and started to run instead of walk." 
PACE is also a verb meaning to step or walk. 
"He PACED back and forth across the room."

METHOD.deftext:
a way, manner, system 
A METHOD is an orderly, logical way of doing something. 
"There are several METHODS for teaching words." 
"His METHOD for doing jigsaw puzzles is quite different from my system." 
"It takes days to learn the right METHOD for operating this machine." 
A METHODICAL person does everything in an orderly way, according to a METHOD. He always thinks things through before acting. 
"He was very METHODICAL about dressing. He put everything on in a certain order and in a certain way." 
Other forms of the word: METHODICAL, adj.

RETREAT.deftext:
to go back, draw back, withdraw 
To RETREAT is to go back, especially from a dangerous or difficult situation. 
"When the enemy attacked, the army was forced to RETREAT." 
"If we RETREAT, will people think we are cowards?" 
RETREAT is also a noun. 
"The general said that a RETREAT was the only way to save the army."

RECKLESS.deftext:
careless, heedless, rash, foolhardy, wild 
See _-less_ under Suffixes. RECK is an old word which means to _take care_, _be concerned_. Someone who is RECKLESS does not take enough care, is thoughtless or wild. 
"The RECKLESS driver went down the narrow street at a hundred miles per hour." "He raced after the criminal, completely RECKLESS of the danger." "She lost everything she owned through her RECKLESS gambling."

SWIFT.deftext:
fast, quick, prompt 
SWIFT means _fast_ or _quick_; the word usually suggests smoothness of movement. 
"We had all we could do to keep from overturning in the SWIFT waters of the river." 
"He ran so SWIFTLY that the others never caught up with him." 
"The days of summer pass SWIFTLY and the vacation is over before you know it." 
"There was a SWIFT change in the weather from blue skies to heavy rain."

REGAIN.deftext:
to get back, recover 
See _re-_ under Prefixes. To REGAIN something is to gain it or get it back after you have lost it. The word is usually used about qualities or states rather than physical objects. 
"After being in prison for ten years, he finally REGAINED his freedom." 
"It took Jane a while to REGAIN her health after her operation." 
"They lost the lead, then REGAINED it." 
"He REGAINED his balance after nearly slipping on the ice."

OPPORTUNITY.deftext:
a chance 
An OPPORTUNITY is a favorable time or chance for doing something. 
"This is a golden OPPORTUNITY for making all kinds of money." 
"If I only had the OPPORTUNITY I'd show them what a good player I am." 
"We had plenty of OPPORTUNITIES to win. We just couldn't seem to take advantage of them." 
"Jane had no OPPORTUNITY to speak to the teacher after school." 
Usage: OPPORTUNITY is often followed by _to_ or _for_.

IRRITATE.deftext:
to annoy, cause anger; to make sore, inflame 
See _-ate2_ under Suffixes. IRRITATE has two different meanings. To IRRITATE someone is to cause him to become angry, to annoy him. 
"The student's endless questions quickly IRRITATED the impatient teacher." 
"After several weeks, Jane found her roommate's sloppy habits to be extremely IRRITATING." 
"The mother was very IRRITATED by her children's constant whining." 
In another sense, to IRRITATE something is to cause it to become sore or inflamed. 
"The woman's eyes were IRRITATED by the smoke-filled air." 
IRRITABLE is the adjective from IRRITATE and means _bad-tempered_. 
"Hot weather always made him very IRRITABLE, and on those days we tried our best to avoid him." 
Other forms of the word: IRRITABLE, adj. IRRITATION, n.

REQUEST.deftext:
to ask, ask for 
To REQUEST something is to ask for it, usually very politely. 
"He REQUESTED a new pair of shoes from his parents." 
"I REQUESTED him to come early." 
"All I REQUEST of you is that you be on time." 
"They REQUEST that we be silent until they are finished." 
REQUEST is also a noun. 
"At their REQUEST we shall come to the party." 
"They turned down his REQUEST for a raise."

POSE.deftext:
a position of the body, attitude 
A POSE is a fixed position of the body, especially one that is taken up while your picture is being taken or painted. 
"He had an odd POSE in the painting, leaning to the side with one foot in the air." 
POSE has also come to mean any way of behaving which may seem unnatural or put on just to impress people. 
"She acted very friendly towards us, but it was all just a POSE. Really she disliked us intensely." 
As a verb, POSE means "to hold a physical position." 
"His wife used to POSE for his paintings." 
It can also mean "to take on a false character, to claim to be." 
"The robber POSED as a janitor in order to get into the apartment."

INVESTIGATE.deftext:
to look into, examine in detail, study 
INVESTIGATE comes from the Latin word for _footprint_. The word was used in Latin when talking about tracking down animals by following their footprints. In English, to INVESTIGATE something is to make careful study of it, to look into it closely. 
"The policeman INVESTIGATED the crime." 
"We will have to INVESTIGATE how much a new radio costs." 
"He INVESTIGATED the area for clues." 
Many people confuse the meaning of INVESTIGATE with the word prove. You might INVESTIGATE a crime, for example, to prove who did it, but INVESTIGATE only means to look into or study. Other forms of the word: INVESTIGATION, n.

questions.prompt: Would you need to use CAUTION if you were walking on a tightrope?
Do most people favor the ELIMINATION of war?
Does a BANDIT break the law?
Are TIRESOME people fun to be with?
Are there NUMEROUS stars in the sky?
Are the stars DISTANT from Earth?
Can people live at a low ALTITUDE?
Is a summer job a PERMANENT one?
Is there a BORDER between the United States and Canada?
When you buy a book, does it usually have to be ASSEMBLED?
Would a six-foot-wide potato be PECULIAR?
Her mother MISTREATED her to another piece of cake after supper.
Bill gets FURIOUS whenever anyone is late for an appointment with him.
He CAUTIOUSLY avoided going near the large dog.
We don't care if we make a smaller QUANTITY of chairs, as long as the quality remains good.
His library card EXPIRED six months ago.
They tried to ELIMINATE her from the race because she was too young.
BANDITS of armed men wandered through the streets of the deserted city.
He was so TIRESOME after the long trip that he fell asleep right away.
We could barely see them on the DISTANT hill.
Jim grew to an ALTITUDE of well over six feet.
This was supposed to be our PERMANENT home, but we moved again after a few years.
Soldiers patrolled the BORDER between the two countries.
They ASSEMBLED each other so much we thought they were twins.
This fish is PECULIAR to the Pacific Ocean.

MISTREAT.deftext:
to treat badly, abuse 
See _mis-_ under Prefixes. To MISTREAT someone is to treat him badly, to do wrong to him, either physically or in some other way. 
"Look at all the cuts on that dog. I think his owner MISTREATS him." 
"Alice complained that she had been MISTREATED by her teachers." 
"The parents were accused of MISTREATING their children by not giving them enough to eat." 
Cheat is often chosen as the meaning of MISTREAT on the Pretest. MISTREAT is a much more general word than cheat, however. You can MISTREAT a person by doing wrong to him in any way, not just by cheating him. Other forms of the word: MISTREATMENT, n.

definitions.deftext:
angry, violent, stormy, fierce 
FURY is violent anger. 
"The mother was filled with FURY when she saw them hurting her child." FURIOUS is the adjective from FURY. See _-ous_ under Suffixes. Someone who is FURIOUS is full of wild anger. 
"Her father was FURIOUS when Jill wrecked his car." 
"She was mildly upset, but everyone else was really FURIOUS." FURIOUS also means "full of activity," wild, energetic. 
"He put on a FURIOUS finish to come from behind and win the race." 
"With one FURIOUS burst of activity, they completely cleaned the house in two hours." 
Other forms of the word: FURY, n.

CAUTIOUS.deftext:
careful, watchful 
To be CAUTIOUS is to be careful, to pay close attention so that you don't make a mistake or so that you don't hurt anyone. 
"You must be CAUTIOUS when you cross a busy street." 
"She patted the kitten CAUTIOUSLY so that it wouldn't become alarmed and run away." 
"The burglar made a CAUTIOUS approach to the darkened house." 
CAUTION is the noun from CAUTIOUS; it means _care_, _alertness_. 
"You must use CAUTION when dealing with poisons." 
"He answered with a great deal of CAUTION. He was afraid to say something he didn't mean." 
Other forms of the word: CAUTION, n., v.

QUANTITY.deftext:
an amount, number 
QUANTITY is something that can be measured. When you ask "How much?" or "How many?" you are asking about the QUANTITY of something. 
"There is a large QUANTITY of dog food left over." 
"We need a small QUANTITY of nails to build this bookcase." 
Many people pick value as the meaning of QUANTITY. This is probably due to a confusion between QUANTITY and _quality_. _Quality_ has to do with how good something is. 
"We're not interested in _quality_ but in QUANTITY. We don't care how good they are as long as there are a lot of them."

EXPIRE.deftext:
to die, come to an end, cease 
See _ex-_ under Prefixes. EXPIRE originally meant "to breathe out." From this it has come to mean "to breathe one's last," to _die_. When used about people the word always means to _die_. 
"After a long illness, he EXPIRED early this morning." When used about things it means to end or cease. 
"The contract will EXPIRE at midnight"—that is, it will no longer be in effect after that time. 
"The senator's term of office will EXPIRE next year." 
With food, the word means to _go bad_. 
"Her roommate threw out the expired milk." 
Other forms of the word: EXPIRATION, n.

ELIMINATE.deftext:
to remove, get rid of, throw out, take away 
ELIMINATE comes from a Latin word which means "to throw out of doors," and this is the original meaning of the word. See _ex-_ under Prefixes. Today the word simply means to throw out or get rid of, and doesn't necessarily mean to throw something outside. 
"The doctors found a new medicine that completely ELIMINATED the disease." 
"The judges ELIMINATED him from the contest." 
The noun form of ELIMINATE is ELIMINATION. An "ELIMINATION tournament" is one in which the loser of a game or match is removed from the competition. 
Other forms of the word: ELIMINATION, n.

BANDIT.deftext:
a robber, outlaw 
A BANDIT was originally a member of a gang of people who banded together in order to rob. Now BANDIT is used about anyone who robs people, alone or as part of a gang. 
"He was held up by a BANDIT in broad daylight." 
"The BANDITS fled to a cabin in the hills."

TIRESOME.deftext:
boring, tedious, dull, annoying 
Something that is TIRESOME makes you tired. The word is usually used about people or things that are so boring they make you want to fall asleep. The word, however, does not mean _tired_; it means _causing tiredness_. 
"Having to write the same sentence fifty times is an extremely TIRESOME exercise." 
"Jim can make exciting events seem TIRESOME." 
Sometimes TIRESOME suggests the meaning _annoying_ more than _boring_. 
"She was a very TIRESOME person to deal with, always whining and complaining."

NUMEROUS.deftext:
many 
NUMEROUS comes from the Latin word for _number_. The word means "great in number," _many_. See _-ous_ under Suffixes. "There are NUMEROUS reasons why we can't come. I will only tell you a few." 
"NUMEROUS people applied for the job, but only one would get it." 
"The people who helped me are too NUMEROUS to mention." 
"NUMEROUS colleges want our star quarterback to play for them."

DISTANT.deftext:
far off 
DISTANT means _far off_, _far away_. 
"Jim wanted to leave home and travel to DISTANT lands." 
"The sound of DISTANT church bells came faintly to us." 
"The sun is 93 million miles DISTANT from the Earth." 
DISTANT can be used about time as well as space. 
"In the DISTANT past people lived in caves and not in houses." 
Other forms of the word: DISTANCE, n.

ALTITUDE.deftext:
height 
ALTITUDE refers to height from earth. It is used about things, not people. 
"The planes rose to an ALTITUDE of 20,000 feet above sea level." 
"The city is located in the mountains at an ALTITUDE of 5,000 feet." 
"At this ALTITUDE it becomes very difficult to breathe." 
The ALTITUDE of something can be described as either high or low. 
"He flew the helicopter at a very low ALTITUDE as he tried to spot where the plane had crashed."

PERMANENT.deftext:
lasting, unchanging 
PERMANENT means _lasting_, "meant to be the same for a long time." 
"This is only my summer home; my PERMANENT home is in New York City." 
"After several temporary jobs, he got a PERMANENT job in the post office." 
"He received a PERMANENT injury from the accident." 
"The dentist put a PERMANENT filling in the patient's tooth." 
Other forms of the word: PERMANENCE, n.

BORDER.deftext:
edge, boundary, frontier 
BORDER has many meanings and uses, but the main one is the _edge_ of something. "There was a BORDER of gold around the invitation." 
A BORDER is a boundary between two countries. "We crossed the BORDER into Canada late in the afternoon." 
"You have to stop at the BORDER and show your passport." 
BORDER is also a verb which means "to lie along or be adjacent to the BORDER of." 
"Our farm BORDERS the state highway." 
"The city is BORDERED by the ocean to the east."

ASSEMBLE.deftext:
to bring together, gather together 
ASSEMBLE means to _bring together_ or _gather together_. The word usually suggests an orderly gathering of people with a common purpose. 
"The troops were ASSEMBLED on the parade ground." 
"The senators will ASSEMBLE tomorrow to vote on the new law." 
ASSEMBLE can also mean to _put together_. 
"It took us three days to ASSEMBLE the jigsaw puzzle." 
"He thinks he can ASSEMBLE a new car from the parts of old ones." 
Other forms of the word: ASSEMBLY, n.

PECULIAR.deftext:
odd, strange, different, unusual; unique, characteristic 
PECULIAR means odd, strange, "different from anyone or anything else." 
"He had a PECULIAR way of talking that no one else could imitate." 
"It was very PECULIAR that everyone was absent on the same day." 
Another meaning of PECULIAR is "belonging only to one person, group, place, or the like." 
In this sense PECULIAR is usually followed by _to_. 
"This kind of house is PECULIAR to New England. You won't find it anywhere else." 
Other forms of the word: PECULIARITY, n.

questions.prompt: Can you DEFEND a person with words?
Does a tall tree ERUPT from the ground overnight?
Do people usually BLUSH because they are sleepy?
Are houses CONSTRUCTED before people live in them?
Does taking a shower make you GRIMY?
Does a small dog have a HANDICAP in a fight with a large one?
Is it DISGRACEFUL to help someone in need?
Is cheese used as BAIT to catch mice?
He EXHALED the wonderful smell of bread baking.
The car went out of control and HURDLED into the wall.
He kept DEFENDING them until finally they called the police, and he was ar rested.
It was a HAZARDOUS job, so no one wanted to do it.
An outburst of applause ERUPTED from the audience when the act was over.
She couldn't CONCEAL how happy she was to see them.
She BLUSHED when he told her he loved her.
We EXAMINED the paper carefully to see if there were any mistakes.
She cleaned the room and CONSTRUCTED it every day.
Your actions were against REGULATIONS, and you must be punished.
The rain washed away some of the GRIME on his face.
In the race, the faster drivers were given the HANDICAP of a head start.
His manners are a DISGRACE. No one should eat with him.
The students BAITED the teacher by making fun of everything he said and did.
The SPLENDOR of the sight made us gasp.

EXHALE.deftext:
to breathe out 
See _ex-_ under Prefixes. To EXHALE is to breathe out. 
"He took a deep breath, then EXHALED slowly." 
"He EXHALED the air from his lungs." 
The opposite of EXHALE is INHALE, to breathe in. Other forms of the word: EXHALATION, n.

HURDLE.deftext:
to jump over, overcome, surmount 
A HURDLE is an obstacle that you jump over in certain running races. To HURDLE something is to jump over it the way a runner would jump over a HURDLE. 
"With one tremendous leap, the horse HURDLED the high fence." 
You can HURDLE any kind of obstacle or barrier. 
"If we can HURDLE this final problem the project will be a success." 
"Students had to HURDLE a difficult series of tests before they were admitted to the school." 
HURDLE is sometimes confused with _hurtle_, which means "to move with great speed." 
"He _hurtled_ down the mountainside, HURDLING several fallen trees along the way."

DEFEND.deftext:
to protect, guard 
To DEFEND something is to protect it, to keep it from harm. 
"The high wall DEFENDS the city against its enemies." 
"His friends DEFENDED him when he was being attacked." 
You can DEFEND someone from other things besides physical harm. 
"The teacher DEFENDED Bill's right to say what was on his mind." 
The act of DEFENDING is called DEFENSE. 
"In DEFENSE of their kittens, mother cats will attack much larger animals." 
"The government spends a great deal of money for the DEFENSE of the country." 
Other forms of the word: DEFENSE, n.

HAZARD.deftext:
danger, risk, peril 
Originally HAZARD was a game of chance using dice. HAZARD has come to be used about anything that has a chance of being harmful, a possible source of danger or injury. "The ice on the roads is a real HAZARD to drivers." 
"The building inspector said that the loose electrical wires were a HAZARD." 
The adjective from HAZARD is HAZARDOUS, meaning _dangerous_ or _risky_. 
"Cigarette smoking is HAZARDOUS to your health." 
"Going over Niagara Falls in a barrel is certainly a HAZARDOUS feat." 
Other forms of the word: HAZARDOUS, adj.

ERUPT.deftext:
to burst forth, explode, break out 
To ERUPT is to burst forth, suddenly and usually violently. See _ex-_ under Prefixes. When a volcano ERUPTS, steam and lava pour out of it. 
"A cheer ERUPTED from the crowd when we scored the winning touchdown." 
"Her face ERUPTS in a rash whenever she eats strawberries." 
"Hal kept his anger under control all day, but it finally ERUPTED at something Ann said." 
An ERUPTION is an outburst or an explosion. 
"The sudden ERUPTION of fighting between the two countries surprised everyone." 
Other forms of the word: ERUPTION, n.

CONCEAL.deftext:
to hide, keep secret 
To CONCEAL something is to hide it from sight. 
"Ann CONCEALED the letter under her pillow." 
"He CONCEALED his face with a mask." 
"Several large trees CONCEALED the house from view." 
You can also CONCEAL ideas, plans, conditions, facts, and so on. 
"He cleverly CONCEALED his real opinion by agreeing with everything we said." 
"It was impossible to CONCEAL the truth from her. She guessed it right away." 
Other forms of the word: CONCEALMENT, n.

BLUSH.deftext:
v.: to redden, become red 
BLUSH means to _redden_ or to _become red_. When people BLUSH, their faces become red, usually because they are embarrassed or ashamed. 
"David BLUSHED as he accepted the award for being the top student." 
"She tries hard to appear calm, but whenever she meets him she BLUSHES." 
BLUSH is also used as a noun. 
"Andy covered his face with his hands to hide his BLUSHES." 
"Samantha admitted with a BLUSH that she had lied."

EXAMINE.deftext:
to look at carefully, search, inspect, test, question 
To EXAMINE something is to look at it carefully in order to find out something about it or to learn from it. You can EXAMINE things. 
"He EXAMINED the boat for leaks." 
"The dentist EXAMINED his teeth." 
Or you can EXAMINE people, by asking questions instead of just looking. 
"The lawyer EXAMINED the witness." 
"The teacher EXAMINED the students in algebra." 
An EXAMINATION is an act of EXAMINING, a test. 
"Did you pass the final EXAMINATION?" 
"The luggage underwent a thorough EXAMINATION." 
Other forms of the word: EXAMINATION, n.

CONSTRUCT.deftext:
to build, put together 
CONSTRUCT means to _build_, especially by putting together parts. 
"We are going to CONSTRUCT a small shed in our backyard for all the gardening equipment." 
"That big hotel was CONSTRUCTED in less than six months." 
You can CONSTRUCT other things besides buildings. 
"He can CONSTRUCT a kite out of newspaper and cardboard." 
"She CONSTRUCTED her argument very carefully by putting all the facts together and in order." 
Other forms of the word: CONSTRUCTION, n.

REGULATION.deftext:
a rule, order 
A REGULATION is a rule, an order which must be followed. 
"It says in the school REGULATIONS that you are to be here by 8:30." 
"They were careful to follow all the safety REGULATIONS." 
"None of the REGULATIONS covers this particular problem." 
"It is against company REGULATIONS for a worker to be absent without good reason." 
Other forms of the word: REGULATE, v. REGULATORY, adj.

GRIME.deftext:
dirt, soot, dust 
GRIME is dirt, especially a coating of dirt on the surface of something. 
"There was a layer of GRIME on the windowsill that no amount of scrubbing could remove." 
"After working in the mine all day his face was covered with GRIME." 
GRIMY means "covered with GRIME," _dirty_. 
"Don't touch that white tablecloth with your GRIMY hands." 
Other forms of the word: GRIMY, adj.

HANDICAP.deftext:
a disadvantage, disability 
HANDICAP is a term in horse racing. In some races, in order to make them fairer or more exciting, the faster horses are given more weight to carry than the slower horses. This extra weight is called a HANDICAP. HANDICAP has come into general use, meaning "any kind of burden or disadvantage which lessens your chance of success." 
"His poor background in mathematics was quite a HANDICAP when he tried to study engineering." 
"She didn't think of her blindness as a HANDICAP; she thought of it as a challenge to be overcome." 
HANDICAP can also be a verb. 
"We were HANDICAPPED by our inability to speak Spanish."

DISGRACE.deftext:
shame, dishonor 
See _dis-_ under Prefixes. One meaning of _grace_ is _favor_ or _goodwill_. To be in someone's "good graces" is to enjoy his honor and approval. DISGRACE is a lack of _grace_; it is shame or dishonor. 
"His crimes brought DISGRACE on his entire family." 
A DISGRACE is also the thing or person that causes the shame. 
"That worker is a DISGRACE to the company. He should be fired." 
Something which is DISGRACEFUL causes DISGRACE. 
"Your conduct is DISGRACEFUL. You should be ashamed of yourself." 
Other forms of the word: DISGRACEFUL, adj.

BAIT.deftext:
to lure, entice; to attack, tease, harass _BAIT is related to the word _bite_. BAIT as a noun is food, or something like food, put on a hook to attract a fish. As a verb, BAIT has developed two different meanings. To BAIT someone can be to lure them the way a fish is lured, by holding out something to tempt them. "The phony message BAITED the enemy into attacking us just where we wanted them to." 
To BAIT is also to torment, annoy, or harass, usually in speech or writing. 
"An angry woman in the crowd BAITED the speaker until he lost his temper." 
"The other team BAITED us the whole game about our poor record."

SPLENDID.deftext:
magnificent, grand, excellent 
SPLENDID comes from a Latin word meaning to _shine_. Something that is SPLENDID shines out; it is brilliant or magnificent. 
"She looked SPLENDID in her fancy new gown." 
"This is a SPLENDID book. I recommend it highly." 
"We had a SPLENDID opportunity to score, but we weren't able to." 
The noun from SPLENDID is SPLENDOR. SPLENDOR is _magnificence_ or _excellence_. 
"We were amazed by the SPLENDOR of every room in the palace." 
Other forms of the word: SPLENDOR, n.
