questions.prompt: Does a TRAGEDY have a happy ending?
Are some PORTIONS larger than others?
Would a person who is under a lot of STRESS usually be carefree and happy?
Do businesses like people to NEGLECT to pay their bills?
Would most people OBJECT to receiving a present?
Would you RECOMMEND buying a phone that doesn't work?
Is it POSSIBLE to see something that is invisible?
Do most people like to get the right SOLUTION to a problem?
Do Americans OBSERVE the Fourth of July as a holiday?
Can a movie theater LURE customers by showing terrible movies?
Does it take money to PURCHASE most things?
Would a person caught outside in a snowstorm feel SNUG?
She is so tender-hearted that even the death of an ant strikes her as TRAGIC.
Please read the PORTION of the story starting on page 35 and ending on page
After the program was over it was INTERRUPTED.
The child made a MOUND of rocks at the beach.
The doctor STRESSED the importance of keeping fit.
She put the "Do Not Disturb" sign on her door to prevent any INTRUSIONS.
He NEGLECTED some of the small details and concentrated on the important problems.
Their OBJECTION was to make it to the top of the mountain before dark.
They RECOMMENDED that we leave early if we wanted to get to the show on time.
We thought that there was no POSSIBILITY that we could lose the game.
Her SOLUTION for any problem was to forget about it.
He OBSERVED that the days got longer in the springtime.
We put some food at the bottom of the tree to LURE the kitten down.
Because he needed money, Tom was forced to PURCHASE his car.
She was quite SNUG in her comfortable chair by the fireplace.

TRAGEDY.deftext:
a disaster, calamity, misfortune 
A TRAGEDY is a very sad event that usually ends in some kind of misfortune or disaster. Originally, a TRAGEDY was a play that ended very unhappily, the opposite of _comedy_. Now, in addition to being a play or book with a sad ending, a TRAGEDY is any kind of disaster that can happen to a person. 
"We were all saddened by the TRAGEDY of the president's death." 
"He acted as if it were a TRAGEDY that he couldn't have the car that evening." 
The adjective from TRAGEDY is TRAGIC, which means _very sad_, _unfortunate_. 
"The once famous star died in TRAGIC circumstances." 
"He has such a low, sad voice that everything he says sounds TRAGIC." 
Other forms of the word: TRAGIC, adj.

PORTION.deftext:
a share, part 
A PORTION is a part or share in something. 
"I think that his PORTION of the money is larger than mine." 
"Each child received a PORTION of the marbles." 
The word is often used about food, meaning "the share of the food given to one person." 
"The restaurant gave them such large PORTIONS that no one could finish."

MOUND.deftext:
a pile, heap, small hill 
A MOUND is a small pile. The word is often used about piled-up earth. 
"The small MOUND in the backyard made them think something might be buried there." 
MOUND can also be used about anything that is piled up. 
"There was a MOUND of dishes in the sink." 
"He had a MOUND of dirty clothes in his room."

INTERRUPT.deftext:
to break in on, break off 
To INTERRUPT someone is to break in on him while he is doing or saying something, so that he has to stop. 
"She kept INTERRUPTING the teacher to ask silly questions." 
"I locked the door of my room so that I wouldn't be INTERRUPTED while I was studying." 
You can also INTERRUPT things like programs. 
"They INTERRUPTED the program to give a special news bulletin." 
Other forms of the word: INTERRUPTION, n.

STRESS.deftext:
pressure, emphasis 
STRESS is a noun and a verb. It has several different uses, all having to do with pressure or importance put on something. STRESS can mean _importance_ or _emphasis_. 
"They place too much STRESS on having a winning football team at that school." 
It is the _force_ with which a particular word is spoken. 
"He always STRESSED the first word in the sentence." 
STRESS is also mental or emotional pressure. 
"With all her problems, she has been under a lot of STRESS lately." 
_Danger_ is often chosen as a meaning of STRESS on the Pretest. _Danger_ might cause STRESS in the sense of mental pressure, but the words have different meanings.

INTRUDE.deftext:
to enter or come uninvited, trespass 
To INTRUDE is to force yourself into a place where you are not welcome. 
"I hope I'm not INTRUDING on you, but I'd like to talk with you for a few minutes." 
"People are always INTRUDING on my privacy." 
Other things besides people can INTRUDE. 
"The noises INTRUDED on my thoughts." 
An INTRUSION is an act of INTRUDING. 
"I was annoyed at these constant INTRUSIONS." 
Other forms of the word: INTRUDER, n. INTRUSION, n. INTRUSIVE, adj. Usage: INTRUDE is usually followed by _on_ or _upon_.

NEGLECT.deftext:
to fail to do, overlook, forget 
To NEGLECT to do something is to fail to do it, either purposely or not. 
"Bill NEGLECTED to follow the instructions, and as a result he did it all wrong." 
"Mary's mother got mad at her when she NEGLECTED to make her bed." 
In a slightly different use, to NEGLECT something is to fail to pay proper attention to it, to ignore it. 
"They NEGLECTED their homework in order to watch television." 
"Sally's parents were so busy with other matters that they often NEGLECTED her." 
Other forms of the word: NEGLECTFUL, adj.

OBJECTION.deftext:
a protest 
To OBJECT to something is to speak in opposition to it. 
"I OBJECT to the way you keep calling me a child. I'm practically an adult." 
An OBJECTION is something said in opposition, disagreement, or refusal. 
"When we asked if we could go, he said he had no OBJECTION." 
"Their OBJECTION to our plan was that it would cost too much money." 
"I raised a strong OBJECTION to the idea of starting the game later." 
Other forms of the word: OBJECT, v.

RECOMMEND.deftext:
to speak favorably of, advise, suggest 
To RECOMMEND is to speak favorably of, to say that someone or something is suited for a job or a purpose. 
"I RECOMMEND him to you highly. He's perfect for the job." 
"We RECOMMEND this paint for your house. It will last for years." 
When you RECOMMEND that someone do something, you suggest it as a good thing to do. 
"The teacher RECOMMENDS that Susan watch less television and study more." 
"The doctor RECOMMENDS that you stay in bed today." 
Other forms of the word: RECOMMENDATION, n.

POSSIBILITY.deftext:
chance, likelihood 
Something that is POSSIBLE can be done or can happen. 
"It is POSSIBLE that we will all pass the test." 
POSSIBILITY is the state of being POSSIBLE. If there is a POSSIBILITY of something happening, we are not sure that it will happen, but it may happen. 
"There is a POSSIBILITY that it will rain tomorrow." 
"Is there any POSSIBILITY that you will be here early?" 
Other forms of the word: POSSIBLE, adj.

SOLUTION.deftext:
an answer, explanation 
SOLUTION is the noun from the verb to solve. A SOLUTION is the answer to a problem or the explanation of a difficulty or a mystery. 
"Everyone has suggestions about how to find the SOLUTION to the unemployment problem." 
"Tom spent hours puzzling over the question without success, but Richard saw the SOLUTION immediately." 
"A fight is not the best SOLUTION for a disagreement."

OBSERVE.deftext:
to note, notice, watch carefully; to pay attention to; to remark, comment 
OBSERVE has several common meanings. To OBSERVE something is to watch it carefully, to take notice of it. 
"He OBSERVED them walking down the street just before dawn." 
"She OBSERVED that the animals in the zoo didn't like the new lights." 
To OBSERVE a rule is to follow it. To OBSERVE a holiday is to celebrate it. To OBSERVE also means "to say by way of a comment." 
" 'I think they're getting tired,' Mary OBSERVED, as she watched the children play." 
Other forms of the word: OBSERVANCE, n. OBSERVATION, n. OBSERVATORY, n.

LURE.deftext:
to tempt, attract, entice 
Originally, a LURE was a bunch of feathers roughly resembling a bird which was used to attract and recall a trained hawk from its flight. From this the word came to be used about anything that attracts or tempts someone. 
"The LURE of the sea has drawn many men away from their homes." 
To LURE therefore means to attract or tempt. 
"The football game on TV LURED them away from their homework." 
"The hope of becoming rich LURED many people to California during the Gold Rush." 
The artificial bait used by fishers is also called a LURE.

PURCHASE.deftext:
to buy 
To PURCHASE something is to buy it. 
"We always PURCHASE our groceries at the supermarket." 
"He went to the city to PURCHASE a ring." 
"Money can't PURCHASE love." 
PURCHASE is also a noun, meaning "something that is bought." 
"She put all her PURCHASES into one bag." 
Most people who get this item wrong think PURCHASE means sell, which is the exact opposite of the correct meaning.

SNUG.deftext:
comfortable, cozy, warm 
SNUG was originally used about ships that are neat and well-prepared for bad weather. To be SNUG now means to be _comfortable_, especially to be warm and dry and protected from the weather. 
"She felt very SNUG in her warm bed as she listened to the wind howl outside." 
SNUG is also used about places and things that make us feel comfortable. 
"As he shoveled snow he wished he were back in his SNUG little room sitting by the fireplace." 
In a different sense, SNUG means closely fitting, tight. 
"This coat is a bit SNUG. Perhaps I should try on a larger size."

questions.prompt: Do people ordinarily show their AFFECTION by kicking each other?
Is the wheel a MODERN invention?
If something is unique, does it have any DUPLICATES?
Can a person HESITATE while he is writing?
Can you FLING a refrigerator very far?
If the sky is OVERCAST, is it sunny?
Do people PERSPIRE more when it's cold than when it is hot?
Would a sad story cause people to CHUCKLE?
Is a NUDGE softer than a punch?
Can a DISTRICT be very large?
Is a five dollar bill IDENTICAL to a ten dollar bill?
Can you ATTEND a play that you've never seen before?
She comes from a very AFFECTIONATE family; the children never leave the house without first kissing their mother.
It was a very MODERN idea; no one would have thought such a thing a few years ago.
She DUPLICATED to us about her report card; she had really failed two courses.
Sally HESITATED for several minutes before she agreed.
How far can you FLING that stone?
The teacher became very COMICAL and yelled at us for being late.
I feel as gloomy as the weather when the sky is OVERCAST.
The PERSPIRATION soaked through his shirt as he struggled to lift the boxes.
He CHUCKLED as he remembered the jokes the comedian had told.
He pushed it with all his might but it didn't NUDGE.
This new shampoo is supposed to make your hair GLOSSY.
She lived in a rundown shack in the poor DISTRICT of town.
She wore the IDENTICAL wedding gown that her mother had worn thirty years ago.
Jim CALCULATED the distance from the Earth to the moon.
Because of the rain, the ATTENDANCE at the game was poor.

AFFECTION.deftext:
love, fondness 
AFFECTION is a warm feeling of fondness and tenderness. It is almost the same as love, although usually not quite as strong. 
"He has a very real AFFECTION for his father." 
"He felt little AFFECTION toward the town where he had grown up." 
The adjective form of AFFECTION is AFFECTIONATE, which means _loving_ or _fond_. 
"The teacher's AFFECTIONATE attitude toward the young children makes them like her in return." 
"He gave the dog an AFFECTIONATE pat." 
Other forms of the word: AFFECTIONATE, adj.

MODERN.deftext:
present-day, up-to-date 
MODERN means 
"having to do with present or recent times." 
"It is a MODERN building, built just a few years ago." 
"Are people happier in MODERN times than they were in the past?" 
"She believes that anything that is MODERN is better than something that is old."

DUPLICATE.deftext:
a copy, double 
DUPLICATE is related to the word _double_. 
Both come from a Latin word meaning _two_. A DUPLICATE is an exact copy of something. 
"This machine can make several DUPLICATES of that letter in just a few seconds." 
"The twins are exact DUPLICATES of each other; even their voices sound the same." 
DUPLICATE may also be used as an adjective. 
"We have DUPLICATE keys to the car. We keep one set in the desk." 
As a verb, the word means "to make a copy of." 
"She tried to DUPLICATE the teacher's movements." 
"He DUPLICATED the directions for getting to his house and sent everyone a copy." 
Other forms of the word: DUPLICATION, n.

HESITATE.deftext:
to pause, delay for a moment 
To HESITATE is to show signs of uncertainty by pausing or delaying for a short time. 
"We could tell he had not studied enough from the way he HESITATED before he spelled each word." 
"The cat HESITATED before stepping on the new- fallen snow." 
"If you need anything, do not HESITATE to ask for it." 
HESITATION is the noun from HESITATE. It is the act of pausing or holding back. 
"Midway through the actor's speech there were several long HESITATIONS, and it became obvious that he had forgotten his lines." 
Other forms of the word: HESITANT, adj. HESITATION, n.

FLING.deftext:
to throw, hurl, cast 
FLING means just about the same as _throw_, but often adds a sense of force or violence to _throw_. 
"Angrily he FLUNG the books across the room." 
"Tom FLUNG the stone with all his might." 
"The wrestler FLINGS his opponent to the ground." 
To "FLING your arms up in the air" is to raise them suddenly and unexpectedly. Usage: The past tense of FLING is FLUNG.

COMICAL.deftext:
funny, humorous, amusing 
COMICAL means _funny_ or _amusing_. 
"The puppy’s actions were so COMICAL that we burst out laughing." 
"She entered the room with a COMICAL expression on her face, and we knew that something funny had happened." 
"He tries to amuse us with COMICAL stories, but we don't think they're funny at all." 
The noun form of COMICAL is COMIC. A COMIC is a person who amuses others by telling funny stories and jokes. Other forms of the word: COMIC, n.

OVERCAST.deftext:
cloudy, gloomy 
OVERCAST is used about clouds and the weather and means _clouded over_, _cloudy_. 
"The sky was OVERCAST, and it looked as if it were going to rain." 
"November was filled with cold, OVERCAST days." 
OVERCAST is also a noun. 
"The few breaks in the OVERCAST convinced us that the weather was going to clear up." 
The most popular incorrect answer on the Pretest is _rainy_. OVERCAST just means _cloudy_, however; when the sky is OVERCAST it might or might not rain.

PERSPIRATION.deftext:
sweat 
PERSPIRATION is a polite word for _sweat_. "He was covered with PERSPIRATION after the 100-yard dash." "The horse's PERSPIRATION looks like white foam." "The room was so warm that everyone's face was shining with PERSPIRATION." The verb form is PERSPIRE. "We PERSPIRED in the hot sunlight." 
_Effort_ is often chosen as the meaning of PERSPIRATION. _Effort_ might cause to sweat, but _effort_ and PERSPIRATION are not the same thing. Other forms of the word: PERSPIRE, v.

CHUCKLE.deftext:
to laugh quietly 
To CHUCKLE is to laugh, usually quietly or to yourself. 
"He CHUCKLED while he read the funny story, and sometimes he laughed out loud." 
"You're not supposed to CHUCKLE when Ken is talking to you even if you think he's funny." 
CHUCKLE is also used as a noun and means a laugh. 
"We got a few CHUCKLES out of the show, but in general it wasn't very funny."

NUDGE.deftext:
to touch or push gently 
To NUDGE someone is to touch or push him slightly, in order to call attention to something or to get him to do something. 
"She NUDGED him and pointed to her watch, letting him know it was time to go." 
"We NUDGED Henry forward until he was at the front of the stage." 
NUDGE is also a noun. 
"I gave him a NUDGE and told him to come with me."

GLOSSY.deftext:
smooth and shiny, highly polished 
The GLOSS of something is its smooth, shining surface. 
"Feel the GLOSS of this silk shirt." 
Something which is GLOSSY has a smooth, shining surface. See _-y_ under Suffixes. 
"He polished his car until the entire surface was GLOSSY." 
"You could see your face reflected in his GLOSSY leather shoes." 
Other forms of the word: GLOSS, n.

DISTRICT.deftext:
an area, region 
A DISTRICT is an area that has a special purpose or a special character that makes it different from other areas. It can be either large or small. 
"In New York, the financial DISTRICT is centered around Wall Street." 
"The DISTRICT where we live is marked off by rivers at either end." 
"There isn't any high school in our DISTRICT, so we have to go into the city." 
"Several DISTRICTS of the town were without electricity because of the storm last night." 
The DISTRICT of Columbia is a special area that contains the capital of the United States.

IDENTICAL.deftext:
same Two things that are IDENTICAL are the same; they are exactly alike and agree in every detail. IDENTICAL twins are twins who look exactly alike. 
"This print is IDENTICAL to the one we saw in the art gallery two weeks ago." 
"No two people have IDENTICAL fingerprints. Everyone's fingerprints are different."

CALCULATE.deftext:
to compute, count, figure 
Calculus was a Latin word for _pebble_. People used to use pebbles to help in adding or subtracting numbers. So to CALCULATE is to work with numbers, to _compute_. "If we know how many miles we have to go, we can CALCULATE how long it will take." 
"Jim's father CALCULATED the cost of sending him to college." 
People now often have CALCULATORS to do their CALCULATING for them. 
"We are allowed to use our pocket CALCULATORS during the math test." 
CALCULATING is an adjective meaning _scheming_ or _acting ruthlessly_. 
"We acquired the business thanks to her calculating efforts." 
Another meaning of CALCULATE is to think or suppose from reasoning. 
"I CALCULATED that Smith will win the election." 
Other forms of the word: CALCULATION, n. CALCULATING, adj. CALCULATOR, n.

ATTENDANCE.deftext:
presence 
To ATTEND something is to be present at it. 
"They ATTENDED church every Sunday." 
ATTENDANCE is the noun from ATTEND. ATTENDANCE means the presence of one or more people at some place. 
"We were surprised by the ATTENDANCE of Bill Johnson at Sam's funeral. They had been enemies for years." 
"Seven pupils got certificates for perfect ATTENDANCE this year." 
ATTENDANCE also means "the number of persons who are present at something." 
"School ATTENDANCE has gone down because fewer children are being born." 
"There was a large ATTENDANCE at the concert." 
Other forms of the word: ATTEND, v.

questions.prompt: Do flowers WILT if it doesn't rain for a long time?
If you go to watch a football game, are you a SPECTATOR?
Would a curving road be a DIRECT route between two places?
Would Los Angeles be CONSIDERED a large city?
Does a diver PLUNGE into the water?
Do you have to be CERTAIN of the answer before you ask a question?
Would a severe burn cause AGONY?
Does a soldier standing at attention SLUMP?
Is it COURTEOUS to slam a door in someone's face?
Can you VARY the clothes you wear?
Is "No, you absolutely can't go" a DEFINITE answer?
Is ice SCARCE at the South Pole?
Our excitement began to WILT when it began to appear that we really could win the championship.
The SPECTATOR ruled the country cruelly and unjustly.
What they did to him was DURABLE. They should be arrested.
He went DIRECTLY to the school after leaving his home.
We couldn't understand how the magician was able to TRICKLE us so easily.
He slowed down out of CONSIDERATION for the other people who couldn't walk that fast.
The plane PLUNGED up into the air.
The DELEGATES to the United Nations come from all over the world.
He thought it was a CERTAINTY that he would win the match, but he lost instead.
Nothing could relieve his AGONY when his wife was killed.
He SLUMPED to the ground after being hit by the ball.
The woman complained about the children's lack of COURTESY. None of them would even speak to her.
Her feelings about school VARY; sometimes she likes it, and sometimes she doesn't.
He wanted some DEFINITE news, not just hints and rumors.
That summer there was such a SCARCITY of water that no one was allowed to take a bath.

WILT.deftext:
to droop, sag 
To WILT is to _droop_, to lose freshness or spirit. The word is often used about plants or flowers. 
"The lack of water caused many plants to WILT." 
The word can also be used in a more general sense. 
"Our enthusiasm for the trip started to WILT when we found out how much it was going to cost." 
"The witness's confidence WILTED under the harsh questioning of the lawyer." 
"Our team started well, but WILTED late in the game."

SPECTATOR.deftext:
an onlooker, viewer, watcher 
The form _spect_ is seen in many words and always means to _see_ or to _look at_. Some examples are: _spectacles_ (eyeglasses); _inspect_ (to examine carefully); and _spectacular_ (wonderful to look at). A SPECTATOR is someone who is looking on at what is happening; he does not take part in the event, but simply watches it. 
"The SPECTATORS were amused by the clown." 
"We were unwilling SPECTATORS of the robbery." 
"The SPECTATORS at the tennis match cheered the winner."

DURABLE.deftext:
lasting, enduring, permanent, strong See _-able_ under Suffixes. The _dur_ part of the word comes from a Latin word meaning to _last_. It is also found in the English word _endure_. Something that is DURABLE is able to last. It won't break or fall apart easily. 
"These toys are DURABLE. Your child will use them for years." 
"He was a DURABLE athlete. He never missed a game because of injury." 
"The can opener wasn't very DURABLE. If you dropped it on the floor it would need to be repaired." 
Other forms of the word: DURABILITY, n.

DIRECT.deftext:
straight, straightforward 
DIRECT means _straight_, "going from one point to another by the shortest path." 
"We wanted to take the DIRECT route to the beach, but he wanted to drive all over the place and see the sights." 
"Go DIRECTLY home. Don't stop anywhere." 
DIRECT is also used about other things besides routes and distances, but it has the same general meaning. 
"The accident was a DIRECT result of your carelessness." 
"Don't beat around the bush. I want a DIRECT answer." 
Other forms of the word: DIRECTION, n.

TRICKLE.deftext:
to drip, flow slowly 
TRICKLE means to _drip_ or _flow slowly_. It is used about water, blood, oil, or other liquids. "Blood was TRICKLING out of his mouth." 
"The water TRICKLED out of the faucet." 
TRICKLE can also be used about other things that can be said to flow. 
"The sugar TRICKLED through her fingers." 
"The students TRICKLED out of the classroom." 
TRICKLE is also a noun. 
"She wiped the TRICKLE of blood from his lips." 
_Melt_ is often chosen as the meaning of TRICKLE on the Pretest. Something like an ice cube may TRICKLE as it melts, but things that are not melting may TRICKLE as well.

CONSIDER.deftext:
to think about 
To CONSIDER means to _think about_ in some way. 
"You must CONSIDER how your father will feel if you do that." 
"I've never CONSIDERED him stupid, just a little slow-moving." 
CONSIDERATION is the act of CONSIDERING. 
"You should take into CONSIDERATION the fact that she's only two years old." 
In a different sense, CONSIDERATION means _thoughtfulness_. 
"He showed great CONSIDERATION for his parents by always letting them know when he expected to be back." 
Other forms of the word: CONSIDERATION, n. CONSIDERATE, adj.

PLUNGE.deftext:
to dive, submerge, dip 
To PLUNGE is to dive down into something such as water or a hole. 
"The kite PLUNGED into the lake." 
"Alice lost her balance and PLUNGED into the well." 
To PLUNGE something is to thrust it, throw it, or cause it to fall into something. 
"He PLUNGED the shovel into the ground." 
"She turned out the lights and PLUNGED the room into darkness." 
"The stock market crash PLUNGED the nation into a depression." 
The most commonly chosen incorrect answer is _step_. To _step_ into something is also to go into it, but PLUNGE suggests a much more complete and sudden movement.

DELEGATE.deftext:
a representative, deputy 
A DELEGATE is a person who has the power to act for someone else. The word is often used about people elected to represent a group at a convention or conference. 
"The DELEGATES met to vote on the party's position on these matters." 
"Each class in the school elected a DELEGATE to represent it in the student government." 
DELEGATE is also a verb meaning "to appoint as a representative." 
"We DELEGATED Jim to be the spokesperson for the club." 
DELEGATE can also mean to _entrust_ or _assign_. 
"He DELEGATED complete authority to us to act as we saw fit in this matter." 
Other forms of the word: DELEGATION, n.

CERTAIN.deftext:
sure 
If something is CERTAIN, it is sure; there is no doubt about it. Both people and things can be CERTAIN. 
"Gloria is CERTAIN that it will be sunny on the day of the picnic." 
"A CERTAIN cure for hiccups is to hold your breath." 
"There is no CERTAIN way to prevent war from breaking out." 
The noun form of CERTAIN is CERTAINTY. A CERTAINTY is an outcome or result that is sure; there is no doubt about it. 
"He was assured of winning; it was a CERTAINTY that he would come in first." 
Many people confuse CERTAIN with _right_. You can be CERTAIN of something, though, and be wrong. Other forms of the word: CERTAINTY, n.

AGONY.deftext:
great pain, torment 
AGONY is great pain or suffering, either of the mind or of the body. 
"Her headaches caused her constant AGONY." 
"He felt extreme AGONY when he saw the results of his careless driving." 
"She looked on in AGONY as the soldiers took away all her possessions." 
To AGONIZE is to suffer AGONY. 
"Susan AGONIZED over her hopeless situation, but couldn't do anything about it." 
Other forms of the word: AGONIZE, v. 
AGONIZED, adj. 
AGONIZING, adj.

SLUMP.deftext:
to sag, droop, slouch 
SLUMP means "to drop down heavily," to _sag_ or _slouch_. 
"His shoulders SLUMPED under the weight of the pack he carried." 
Someone who SLUMPS is often tired. 
"He staggered into the room and SLUMPED down into a chair." 
SLUMP is sometimes used of other things besides people. 
"The ice cream business always SLUMPS during the cold weather." 
SLUMP is also a noun. 
"There has been a SLUMP in the price of corn."

COURTEOUS.deftext:
polite, well-mannered 
To be COURTEOUS is to be polite, to have good manners. 
"The COURTEOUS boy held the door open for his mother." 
"Even though he was very angry at the rude question, he managed to give a COURTEOUS answer." 
"With a COURTEOUS smile, she stepped aside to let the woman with all the packages get on the bus first." 
The noun form of COURTEOUS is COURTESY, which means _politeness_ or _polite behavior_. 
"She showed great COURTESY to the unexpected visitor, although she was tired and wanted to go to bed." 
Other forms of the word: COURTESY, n.

VARY.deftext:
to change, become different 
When something VARIES it becomes different. 
"The colors of the sky at sunset VARY from minute to minute." 
To VARY something is to make it different, to change it. 
"She never VARIES her hairstyle; she has always worn it short and curly." 
"He tried to VARY the way he taught the class so that his students wouldn't get bored." 
An adjective form of VARY is VARIABLE, which means _changeable_. 
"The forecast for today says that there will be VARIABLE winds and sunny skies." 
Other forms of the word: VARIABLE, adj. VARIOUS, adj.

DEFINITE.deftext:
exact, clear, precise 
Whatever is clear, exact, and leaves no room for doubt is DEFINITE. 
"We have made DEFINITE plans to leave on Saturday morning." 
"Can you be more DEFINITE about the place where I'm supposed to meet you? So far you've been rather vague." 
"He made a DEFINITE promise to help us." The adverb form, DEFINITELY, is often used to mean _surely_, _positively_, _precisely_. 
"He DEFINITELY has a hearing problem. Three separate ear examinations have confirmed it." 
"I will DEFINITELY be there by ten o'clock."

SCARCE.deftext:
rare, not enough, uncommon 
When something is SCARCE, it is rare or in very short supply. There is hardly any of it. 
"Before these animals were protected by law, they were becoming very SCARCE." 
"When food gets SCARCE, the price goes up." 
"During the strike, steel became very SCARCE in some parts of the country." 
The noun from SCARCE is SCARCITY, which means a _short supply_ of something. 
"There were long lines at gasoline stations because of the SCARCITY of fuel." 
Other forms of the word: SCARCITY, n.

questions.prompt: Should a pilot be able to NAVIGATE a plane?
Is it easy to see a FAINT star?
Is running over a dog HOMICIDE?
Could a person SHRIEK from fear?
Are reading, writing, and arithmetic ELEMENTARY subjects?
Is it easy to INCINERATE gold and silver?
Can you only ASSAULT someone by hitting him?
Do people MUFFLE up in order to keep warm?
Are a father and his son LINKED in any way?
Does an airplane crash usually cause GRIEF?
Could an explosion cause buildings to QUAKE?
The captain let his son NAVIGATE the ship through the canal.
Her cries were too FAINT to be heard in the next room.
He was accused of HOMICIDE in the death of his wife.
The baby's constant SHRIEKS kept us from getting a good night's sleep.
There are some ELEMENTARY things you have to know before you can drive a car.
They INCINERATED that we had made a mistake.
Alice was OCCASIONALLY late for school; she was almost never on time.
The cruel strangers ASSAULTED him with clubs and rocks.
The fielder MUFFLED the easy ground ball.
He HOBBLED to the other side of the room to pick up his crutches.
They LINKED the boat from the dock by cutting the rope.
There was considerable RESISTANCE in Congress to the president's plan.
Only the passage of time could ease the GRIEF she felt over his death.
Beth is very MOODY today. She may yell at you for no reason.
The explosions made the nearby buildings QUAKE.

NAVIGATE.deftext:
to steer, sail 
NAVIGATE is related to the word navy. Both come from a Latin word meaning _ship_. The basic meaning of NAVIGATE is to "steer a ship." Now the word also means to steer or direct your course anywhere, in the water, on the ground, or in the air. "The pilot NAVIGATED the damaged plane to a successful landing." 
"Can you NAVIGATE the boat through the rapids?" 
"We expect you to be able to NAVIGATE anywhere after you have finished this course in sailing." 
Other forms of the word: NAVIGATION, n. 
NAVIGATOR, n.

FAINT.deftext:
dim, weak, unclear, indistinct 
Something that is FAINT lacks strength. A person who "feels FAINT" feels sick and dizzy, as if he or she were about to pass out. FAINT can be used about sounds, lights, smells, memories, and other things. 
"There was a FAINT smell of roses in the air as they approached the garden." 
"He could barely hear the FAINT sound of the distant train whistle." 
"There is only a very FAINT hope that any of the trapped miners will survive." 
The verb to FAINT is usually used about people and means "to lose consciousness," to _pass out_. 
"Many people FAINTED in the heat during the long speech."

HOMICIDE.deftext:
the killing of a human being, murder 
HOMICIDE is the killing of a person by another person. "The medical examiner ruled that the death was a HOMICIDE." 
"The detective was assigned to investigate cases of HOMICIDE." 
HOMICIDE and _murder_ have almost the same meaning, but there is a slight difference. _Murder_ is the _unlawful_ killing of a person. If you kill someone in self-defense, that would be HOMICIDE, but it wouldn't be _murder_, since the killing would be legal. All _murders_ are HOMICIDES, but not all HOMICIDES are _murders_.

SHRIEK.deftext:
to scream, screech, cry out 
To SHRIEK is to scream or screech suddenly or loudly, usually with a very high sound. 
"She SHRIEKED when she heard the unexpected knock on the door." 
SHRIEK is also a noun meaning a _scream_. 
"She let out a piercing SHRIEK when she saw the accident." 
"The SHRIEKS of the angry birds disturbed my nap."

ELEMENTARY.deftext:
basic, fundamental, simple 
An ELEMENT is a basic part of something. The chemical ELEMENTS, for example, are the basic substances like oxygen and carbon which combine to form all matter. Something that is ELEMENTARY, therefore, has to do with the basic or first parts of a subject or a thing. 
"He learned some of the ELEMENTARY steps, but he never became an expert dancer." 
"You have to pass ELEMENTARY French before you can take advanced courses." 
An ELEMENTARY school teaches children basic subjects like reading, writing, and arithmetic. Other forms of the word: ELEMENT, n.

INCINERATE.deftext:
to burn, reduce to ashes 
INCINERATE comes from the Latin word for ashes and means to "burn to ashes." 
"He INCINERATED the pile of leaves in the backyard." 
An INCINERATOR is a place for INCINERATING, a furnace. 
"We placed all the trash in the INCINERATOR." 
Other forms of the word: INCINERATOR, n.

OCCASIONALLY.deftext:
sometimes, now and then, at times 
OCCASIONALLY is an adverb from OCCASIONAL, which means "happening now and then." 
"There were OCCASIONAL mistakes in the book, but in general it was quite good." 
OCCASIONALLY means _at times_, _now and then_. On the Pretest, many people pick _often_ as the meaning of OCCASIONALLY, but something that happens OCCASIONALLY doesn't happen very _often_ at all. 
"She OCCASIONALLY went to the movies, but preferred watching television." 
"We have turkey only OCCASIONALLY—maybe two or three times a year." 
Other forms of the word: OCCASION, n. 
OCCASIONAL, adj.

ASSAULT.deftext:
to attack 
To ASSAULT someone is to attack him, usually violently or suddenly. 
"The three youths ASSAULTED the defenseless girl." 
"The soldiers ASSAULTED the enemy positions." 
ASSAULT is also a noun. 
"We managed to turn back the enemy's ASSAULT." 
Sometimes an ASSAULT can be in words. 
"The mayor considered the newspaper articles to be an ASSAULT on his good reputation."

MUFFLE.deftext:
to wrap up, cover over; to deaden the sound of 
To MUFFLE or MUFFLE up something is to wrap it up. You can MUFFLE something to keep it warm or hide it. 
"She MUFFLED her neck with a scarf." 
"He MUFFLED up in a heavy coat before going out into the cold." 
Or you can MUFFLE something to keep it from being noisy. 
"They tried to MUFFLE the noise of the machine by wrapping it in cotton." 
On a car, a MUFFLER is a device that deadens the sound of the engine. Many people choose move as the meaning of MUFFLE, perhaps because MUFFLE sounds like shuffle, which is a kind of movement. 
Other forms of the word: MUFFLER, n. 
Usage: MUFFLE is sometimes followed by up.

HOBBLE.deftext:
to limp, move awkwardly; to hamper the action of 
To HOBBLE is to walk with difficulty, as if your feet or legs were hurt. 
"The old man HOBBLED down the street, leaning heavily on his cane." 
"With his broken ankle Don can barely HOBBLE." 
To HOBBLE someone or something is to cause it to move awkwardly, to hamper or bother it. 
"The tight-fitting shoes HOBBLED her as she tried to walk across the room."

LINK.deftext:
to join, connect 
A LINK is one of the rings or loops in a chain. To LINK things is to connect them, to join them together the way LINKS are joined in a chain. 
"They built a bridge to LINK the two sides of the river." 
"Our common interest in fishing LINKS us together." 
LINK is often used with _up_. 
"The two ends were LINKED up with one another by means of a rope."

RESIST.deftext:
to oppose, withstand 
To RESIST something is to withstand its power or force. 
"The enemy RESISTED our attack." 
"The youth was charged with RESISTING arrest." 
"I couldn't RESIST buying this necklace." 
"This glass can RESIST temperatures of up to a thousand degrees." 
RESISTANCE is the power of RESISTING. 
"The insects had developed a RESISTANCE to that poison"—that is, they could withstand its effects. 
Other forms of the word: RESISTANCE, n. 
RESISTANT, adj.

GRIEF.deftext:
deep sorrow, sadness, mental suffering, misery 
GRIEF is a very strong degree of _sadness_ or _sorrow_. 
GRIEF usually suggests sadness that is caused by loss, pain, regret, or despair, and that lasts for a long time or is very deep. 
"No one could ease her GRIEF when she discovered that her son had died." 
"Jim's GRIEF over her decision to leave him was almost unbearable." 
The phrase "to come to GRIEF" means "to meet misfortune or disappointment." 
"This project will come to GRIEF unless we work harder." 
The most commonly chosen incorrect answer is _anger_. _Anger_ is another strong emotion, but it is not the same as GRIEF. Other forms of the word: GRIEVE, v.

MOOD.deftext:
a state of mind, feeling 
A MOOD is a state of mind, the way a person feels mentally at a certain time. 
"His MOODS change constantly. He's happy one minute and sad the next." 
"She said she isn't in the MOOD to work right now." 
MOOD is also used about the general spirits of a group of people. 
"The country is in an angry MOOD." 
"His writings reflect the MOOD of the times." 
A person who is MOODY has MOODS that often change. MOODY is usually used about a person who often has unhappy or angry MOODS. 
"He becomes MOODY and won't talk to anyone whenever he loses a game." 
Other forms of the word: MOODY, adj.

QUAKE.deftext:
to shake, tremble 
QUAKE means to _shake_, usually violently. 
"Every time the train roared by the entire house would QUAKE." 
People QUAKE from cold or fear. 
"When I saw the monster I started QUAKING so badly that I couldn't run." 
QUAKE, as a noun, is short for _earthquake_. In an _earthquake_ the ground starts shaking, which causes great damage to buildings and property.

questions.prompt: Would a DEVOTED musician enjoy playing music?
Are the CIRCUMSTANCES of a decision the results of it?
Would most students like to have summer vacations ABOLISHED?
Would a baby BAWL if it hadn't been fed for a day?
Would a coach ENCOURAGE his team to win?
Would most people find it CONVENIENT to go to school next door to where they live?
Would most people want to buy a DEFECTIVE watch?
Do children usually have AUTHORITY over their parents?
Are cars that have been in accidents DEFORMED?
Would a CONFIDENT person worry that he was going to fail?
No one could match the lawyer's DEVOTION to the cause of justice for all.
These are not the proper CIRCUMSTANCES in which to discuss your problems.
The teacher ABOLISHED them not to talk so loud.
The children always became very sad when they spoke about their DECEASED uncle.
She DOZED the baby by singing softly to it.
Pete lost his balance and BAWLED down the stairs.
The ASSASSIN followed his victim for days before killing him.
We were ENCOURAGED by the favorable response to our request.
It costs more, but Mrs. Jones likes the CONVENIENCE of having her groceries delivered right to her door.
There was only one DEFECT in the engine, but it was enough to keep the car from running.
He CIRCULATED the right answer with his pencil and went on to the next question.
A quick ENCOUNTER showed that we were missing six dollars.
Who gave you the AUTHORITY to close the school?
Larry DEFORMED his letters the way the teacher taught him to.
Everyone on the team was CONFIDENT that we would win.

DEVOTION.deftext:
faithfulness, dedication, loyalty 
Someone who is DEVOTED is attached or dedicated to a purpose, cause, or person. 
"They are DEVOTED to the idea of world peace." DEVOTION is the quality of being DEVOTED; it is _faithfulness_, _dedication_, _loyalty_. 
"Everyone admired her DEVOTION to her sick parents." 
"He was fired because he didn't show enough DEVOTION to his duties." 
Other forms of the word: DEVOTE, v. 
DEVOTED, adj.

CIRCUMSTANCE.deftext:
a condition, fact 
CIRCUMSTANCES are the conditions or facts surrounding some event or situation. 
"I cannot make a decision about this until I know all the CIRCUMSTANCES." 
"We were unaware of the terrible CIRCUMSTANCES at his home; both parents were ill and there was no food in the house." 
"Each CIRCUMSTANCE must be taken into account before we decide what to do." 
"She died under mysterious CIRCUMSTANCES." 
Usage: CIRCUMSTANCE is generally used in the plural: CIRCUMSTANCES.

ABOLISH.deftext:
to do away with, end 
To ABOLISH something is to put an end to it or to do away with it. The word is used especially about laws, customs, and practices rather than about physical objects. 
"President Lincoln ABOLISHED slavery in America." 
"Our family voted to ABOLISH the tradition of giving expensive gifts on birthdays." 
"Will mankind ever ABOLISH war?" 
The noun from ABOLISH is ABOLITION. 
"The student council voted for the ABOLITION of the dress code. They said students should wear whatever they like." 
Other forms of the word: ABOLITION, n.

DECEASED.deftext:
dead 
DECEASED means _dead_. It is used only about people, and often refers to someone who is recently dead. 
"The DECEASED man's will was read to his relatives a month after he died." 
"Al Johnson is now DECEASED, but he was once the richest man in town." DECEASED is also a noun and means the dead person. 
"The wishes of the DECEASED must be respected in this matter."

DOZE.deftext:
to sleep lightly 
To DOZE is to fall into a light sleep. 
"He DOZED for a while, then awoke with a start and realized he had missed the TV show." 
"I must have DOZED off while doing my homework." 
DOZE is also a noun. 
"The speech was so boring Joan fell into a DOZE after the first few minutes." 
Usage: DOZE is often followed by _off_.

BAWL.deftext:
to cry loudly, shout 
To BAWL means "to cry or shout loudly and continuously." Babies BAWL; animals BAWL; children who are very unhappy BAWL. 
"We could hear the baby BAWLING in the next room." 
"The cattle in the stockyard BAWLED in fear and confusion." 
When you get "BAWLED out" you get a loud scolding; someone shouts at you for doing something wrong. 
"Her mother BAWLED her out for coming home late."

ASSASSIN.deftext:
a murderer, killer 
An ASSASSIN is a _killer_, especially one who is paid for killing or who kills a public official. 
"They caught the ASSASSIN of the president." 
"The ASSASSIN prepared very carefully to murder his victim." 
The verb from ASSASSIN is ASSASSINATE. 
"Several Roman emperors were ASSASSINATED." 
"The madman ASSASSINATED the mayor." 
Other forms of the word: ASSASSINATE, v. 
ASSASSINATION, n.

ENCOURAGE.deftext:
to put courage into, urge on, stimulate, hearten, foster 
See _in-_ under Prefixes. 
ENCOURAGE basically means "to put courage into." 
"The soldiers needed to be ENCOURAGED before the battle." 
As the word is used today it means to _urge_ or _help_ someone to do something, through words or example or in some other way. 
"Her presence ENCOURAGED him to try again." 
"My parents ENCOURAGED me to be a doctor." What is ENCOURAGED can be either good or bad. 
"His early success ENCOURAGED him in his life of crime." 
It doesn't have to be a person who is ENCOURAGED. 
"The plan was designed to ENCOURAGE small businesses." 
Other forms of the word: ENCOURAGEMENT, n. 
ENCOURAGING, adj.

CONVENIENT.deftext:
handy, useful, suitable 
Something that is CONVENIENT is near at hand or easy to use. It is well suited for your comfort or ease. 
"He found a CONVENIENT spot near the river and pitched his tent there." 
"I don't care when you come. Pick the time that is most CONVENIENT for you." 
"The soap comes in a CONVENIENT new package that we're sure you'll like." 
The noun from CONVENIENT is CONVENIENCE. 
"He arranged the schedule for his own CONVENIENCE. He didn't care if it caused problems for other people." 
Other forms of the word: CONVENIENCE, n.

DEFECT.deftext:
a fault, flaw, imperfection 
A DEFECT is something wrong or damaged, a _fault_. 
"The DEFECT in the jacket was hardly noticeable. It was just a tiny hole near the button." 
"The DEFECT in his plan was that there was no way we could get the money to carry it out." 
"He admitted that his quick temper was a DEFECT in his character." 
The adjective from DEFECT is DEFECTIVE. DEFECTIVE means _damaged_ or _not working_, "having flaws or faults." 
"The lamp was DEFECTIVE: sometimes it would light and sometimes it wouldn't." 
"We didn't realize the air conditioner was DEFECTIVE until we tried to use it." 
Other forms of the word: DEFECTIVE, adj.

CIRCULATE.deftext:
to move around, spread, flow freely 
CIRCULATE is related to the word _circle_. It means "to move around and around." 
"Blood CIRCULATES in our bodies; it takes about ten minutes for a complete cycle." 
"We could hear the water CIRCULATING in the pipes." CIRCULATE also means "to go freely from one place to another," to _spread around_. In this sense the word can be used about ideas, information, and the like. 
"The news of her arrival CIRCULATED through the waiting crowd within a few moments." 
"They CIRCULATED a petition asking that there be less homework on the weekends." 
Other forms of the word: CIRCULATION, n.

ENCOUNTER.deftext:
a chance meeting; a battle, conflict 
An ENCOUNTER is a meeting, especially a face-to-face meeting. There are two different uses of ENCOUNTER. The first is for any casual, unplanned meeting. 
"John had an unexpected ENCOUNTER with his old friend yesterday." 
The second use is for a sudden and perhaps violent coming together of enemies. 
"The bloody ENCOUNTER left six men injured." 
ENCOUNTER is also used as a verb, and means to _come upon_, _meet_, _confront_. 
"The two old enemies ENCOUNTERED each other in the middle of the battle."

AUTHORITY.deftext:
power, right 
AUTHORITY is the power or right to make people do something. 
"He received the AUTHORITY to collect taxes in his district." 
"The AUTHORITY of the laws was disregarded by the rebels." 
"As they grew older, Mrs. Smith's children resisted her AUTHORITY more and more." 
Another meaning of AUTHORITY is "a person who has expert knowledge of something." 
"He became the AUTHORITY on the development of young children." 
"She is an AUTHORITY on Shakespeare."

DEFORMED.deftext:
disfigured, misshapen 
To DEFORM something is to take it out of its natural form or shape. See _de-_ under Prefixes. When something is DEFORMED, then, it is not shaped properly; it is disfigured. 
"His leg was DEFORMED as a result of the accident." 
"The baby survived, but it was permanently DEFORMED." 
DEFORMED usually suggests something that is ugly or offensive. 
"When he was very upset, his face would become DEFORMED with rage." 
In the Pretest, many people choose _destroyed_ as the meaning of DEFORMED. Something that is DEFORMED still exists, it is just misshapen; it has not been _destroyed_. 
Other forms of the word: DEFORM, v. 
DEFORMITY, n.

CONFIDENT.deftext:
sure, assured 
Someone who is CONFIDENT firmly believes that he is right or that he can do something. He doesn't have any fears or doubts about himself. 
"I am CONFIDENT that I will succeed. No one can stop me now." 
"She was CONFIDENT she had passed the exam, but she was surprised she earned an A." 
"The salesman walked CONFIDENTLY up to them and told them why they should buy this car." 
A person who is CONFIDENT has CONFIDENCE. 
"Every success he had gave him a little more CONFIDENCE that he could do the job." 
"All Jim lacks is CONFIDENCE. He just doesn't think he's good enough." 
The most commonly chosen incorrect answer is _mysterious_. This may be because CONFIDENT looks like _confidential_, which means _secret_. 
Other forms of the word: CONFIDENCE, n.

questions.prompt: Can there be only one person on an EXPEDITION?
Does a teacher INSTRUCT a class?
Do babies usually have GNARLED hands?
If you tell someone he is ugly, mean, and stingy, are you FLATTERING him?
Would a speedy person usually LAG behind?
Is a HEX meant to help a person?
Is an IMPOSTOR trying to fool someone?
Does losing often make people feel GLUM?
Is the skin on the INTERIOR of the body?

Does the loser of a game generally feel GLEEFUL?
Beth tried to ESTABLISH a reputation as a hard worker.
The EXPEDITION of jewelry was beautifully arranged in the store window.
We were INSTRUCTED to leave our coats outside the examination room.
The dog GNARLED on the bone for a while before he buried it.
The painting FLATTERED the lady by making her look twenty years younger.
We tried to EXTERMINATE all the insects in the house.
He LAGGED at them for not working harder.
His one error proved to be FATAL, because his team lost as a result of it.
Al believed he was HEXED, because nothing ever seemed to go right for him.
He was a true IMPOSTOR, always trying to help people.
Catherine became GLUM when she heard that she had won the scholarship.
The FEROCIOUS look the teacher gave us made us all quiet down immediately.
The INTERIOR of Australia is mostly desert.
The watch was so EXPENSIVE we couldn't afford to buy it.
With GLEEFUL cries, the children opened their presents on Christmas morning.

ESTABLISH.deftext:
to set up, make firm, start up, bring about, found 
ESTABLISH is related to the adjective _stable_, which means _solid_, _fixed_, _not easily moved_. The basic meaning of ESTABLISH is "to make something stable." The word is usually used in the sense "to set up or bring about something," usually on a firm or stable basis. It is often used about businesses: 
"This company was ESTABLISHED in 1959." 
About customs: 
"Who ESTABLISHED the custom of kissing underneath mistletoe?" 
About rights, claims, facts, and the like: 
"It took a long time to ESTABLISH the facts of the case." 
And about people: 
"They were comfortably ESTABLISHED in their new headquarters." 
In all cases, ESTABLISH has the idea of setting something up, putting something on a firm foundation. 
Other forms of the word: ESTABLISHMENT, n.

EXPEDITION.deftext:
a journey, voyage 
An EXPEDITION is a journey or voyage which usually is made for a definite reason. It is usually well organized, and its purpose is often to explore. 
"He went on an EXPEDITION into the jungle to study the rare plants that grow there." 
"When we had everything packed for our vacation, it looked like we were going on an EXPEDITION to Alaska." 
"The military EXPEDITION lasted two months."

INSTRUCT.deftext:
to teach, educate, inform; to order 
To INSTRUCT someone is to give knowledge to him. Often it means just about the same as teach. 
"The teacher INSTRUCTED the class about how to do multiplication." 
"The piano teacher comes to the house to INSTRUCT Sue." 
Sometimes INSTRUCT has a stronger meaning—to _order_ or _direct_. 
"The teacher INSTRUCTED us to return to our seats immediately." 
The adjective from INSTRUCT is INSTRUCTIVE, which means _giving knowledge_, _informative_. 
"The class was very INSTRUCTIVE. I think we all learned a lot." 
Other forms of the word: INSTRUCTION, n. 
INSTRUCTIVE, adj. 
INSTRUCTOR, n.

GNARLED.deftext:
twisted, rugged, knotty 
GNARLED is used about the rough, twisted, knotty appearance of the branches on oak and other trees. 
"The kite was caught in the GNARLED branches of the tree." 
From this use the word has come to be applied to anything or anyone that looks rugged, tough, or weatherbeaten. 
"His hands were GNARLED from years of hard work." 
"The GNARLED old cowboy told us many exciting tales of his younger days." 
Other forms of the word: GNARL, v.

FLATTER.deftext:
to over praise; to show favorably 
To FLATTER someone is to praise him more than he deserves, usually with the hope of gaining something. 
"The noblemen FLATTERED the king by telling him what a great leader he was." 
"Ted tried to FLATTER her, but she realized he wasn't sincere with his compliments." 
In a related sense, FLATTER means "to show off to advantage." 
"That photograph FLATTERS her. She's not really that good-looking." 
Other forms of the word: FLATTERY, n.

EXTERMINATE.deftext:
to destroy completely, wipe out, put an end to, get rid of 
To EXTERMINATE something is to wipe it out, to destroy it totally. The word is used about people, ideas, pests, diseases, and other things. 
"The enemy tried to EXTERMINATE us, but somehow a few of us managed to survive." 
"Our attempt to EXTERMINATE this new disease was completely successful; no cases of it were reported last year." 
An EXTERMINATOR is someone who EXTERMINATES, particularly someone whose job is to EXTERMINATE insects, rats, or other pests. 
"The new house was so filled with bugs, we had to call the EXTERMINATOR." 
In the Pretest, _stop_ is often chosen as the meaning of EXTERMINATE. EXTERMINATE is a much stronger word than stop, however. To EXTERMINATE means to _destroy completely_. 
Other forms of the word: EXTERMINATION, n. 
EXTERMINATOR, n.

LAG.deftext:
to fall behind, fail to keep up To 
LAG is to go too slow, to fail to keep up the pace. 
"All the runners kept on going, but Jim was tired and LAGGED behind." 
"The two of us LAGGED behind the others so that we could talk some more." 
Sometimes LAG is used to mean "to weaken little by little, to become less active." "After a while his interest in history began to LAG." 
Usage: LAG is often followed by _behind_.

FATAL.deftext:
deadly, mortal, disastrous 
FATE is the influence or power that is supposed to control our lives. 
FATAL is an adjective from FATE. See _-al_ under Suffixes. The basic meaning of FATAL is "determining one's FATE." 
The word is generally used about death, which is everyone's ultimate FATE. A FATAL accident is one that causes death; a FATAL dose of a drug is one large enough to bring about death. Sometimes the word is used about things that are so bad or disastrous that they seem deadly. 
"This one FATAL mistake caused many problems for her later on." 
A FATALITY is a death, usually one caused by an accident or a disaster. 
"The police reported seven FATALITIES on the icy highway that night." 
Other forms of the word: _FATE_, n. _FATALITY_, n.

HEX.deftext:
a curse, evil spell, jinx 
A HEX is an evil spell, a curse that a witch might put on someone. 
"When the machine kept breaking down, it began to look as though someone had put a HEX on it." 
"There must be a HEX on those people; everything they do turns out wrong." 
HEX can also be used as a verb. 
"Dave thought that if anyone even mentioned losing it might somehow HEX the team."

IMPOSTOR.deftext:
a pretender, faker, fraud 
An IMPOSTOR is a person who pretends to be someone he is not. 
"The man said he was from the F.B.I., but he turned out to be an IMPOSTOR." 
"The doctor knew so little about medicine that we accused him of being an IMPOSTOR." 
"It would be impossible for an IMPOSTOR to fool us."

GLUM.deftext:
gloomy, sad, dejected 
GLUM is related to the word _gloom_. Someone who is GLUM is in low spirits; he is in a silent, unhappy mood. 
"The student looked very GLUM as he waited in the principal's office." 
"The GLUM athletes sat silently in the locker room after losing the game." 
"Our mailman always looks GLUM. I don't think he likes his job."

FEROCIOUS.deftext:
fierce, savage, cruel, violently aggressive 
FEROCIOUS is used about animals and people and the way they act. It means "extremely cruel, wild, and savage." 
"The dog was small but FEROCIOUS: it would attack dogs three times its size." 
"The FEROCIOUS battle lasted all day, with neither side giving an inch." 
The noun from FEROCIOUS is FEROCITY. 
"The FEROCITY of his criticism surprised us; we didn't think he had disliked it that much." 
"His FEROCITY when he was angry made everyone afraid of him." 
Other forms of the word: FEROCITY, n.

INTERIOR.deftext:
the inside 
See _in-_ under Prefixes. The INTERIOR of something is its inside. 
"She liked the house from the outside, but thought its INTERIOR was very ugly." 
"He traveled from the coast to the INTERIOR of the country." An "INTERIOR decorator" is a person who decorates the insides of houses and buildings. The opposite of INTERIOR is _exterior_, the _outside_. 
_Decoration_ is often chosen as the meaning of INTERIOR. People who pick decoration have probably heard the phrase INTERIOR _decoration_ but don't know exactly what it means.

EXPENSE.deftext:
price, cost, spending 
The EXPENSE of something is how much it costs, how much you have to pay for it. This cost is usually calculated in terms of money. 
"I want that car, no matter what the EXPENSE." 
"He worried about the EXPENSE of the trip." 
EXPENSE can refer to other things besides money. 
"He stayed outside in the snowstorm, at great EXPENSE to his health"—that is, he paid the price for staying outside by becoming sick. 
"We managed to finish the project, but it required a tremendous EXPENSE of time and energy." Something that is EXPENSIVE causes EXPENSE—costs a lot of money or more than it is worth. 
"This car is too EXPENSIVE; I have to find one that costs less." 
Other forms of the word: EXPEND, v. EXPENSIVE, adj.

GLEEFUL.deftext:
merry, joyous, glad 
GLEE is _joy_, especially joy caused by triumph or success. 
"He shouted with GLEE as they called out his name as the winner." 
GLEEFUL means "full of GLEE." 
"He was GLEEFUL at the news that he had been accepted at college." 
"The GLEEFUL child got onto her new bicycle." 
_Excited_ is a common choice as the meaning of GLEEFUL. A GLEEFUL person will usually be _excited_, but GLEEFUL has to do with joy and happiness, not with excitement. 
Other forms of the word: GLEE, n.
